	<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Hinduism</h1>
	
	<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
		<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
		<div id="contentSub"></div>

</p>

</tr><tr><td class="plainlist" style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;border-top: 1px solid #aaa; border-bottom: 1px solid #aaa;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_Hinduism_terms" title="Glossary of Hinduism terms">Glossary of Hinduism terms</a></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/File:Aum_Om_red.svg" class="image"><img alt="Aum Om red.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Aum_Om_red.svg/16px-Aum_Om_red.svg.png" decoding="async" width="16" height="16" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Aum_Om_red.svg/23px-Aum_Om_red.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Aum_Om_red.svg/31px-Aum_Om_red.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="356" data-file-height="367" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Hinduism" title="Portal:Hinduism">Hinduism&#32;portal</a></i> <a href="/wiki/File:HinduSwastika.svg" class="image"><img alt="HinduSwastika.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/HinduSwastika.svg/15px-HinduSwastika.svg.png" decoding="async" width="15" height="15" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/HinduSwastika.svg/23px-HinduSwastika.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/HinduSwastika.svg/30px-HinduSwastika.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="142" data-file-height="145" /></a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Hinduism" title="Template:Hinduism"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Hinduism" title="Template talk:Hinduism"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Hinduism&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Hinduism</b> is an <a href="/wiki/Indian_religion" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian religion">Indian religion</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">dharma</a></i>, or way of life,<sup id="cite_ref-definition_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-definition-1">&#91;note 1&#93;</a></sup> widely practised in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia" title="Hinduism in Indonesia">parts of Southeast Asia</a>. Hinduism has been called the oldest religion in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">&#91;note 2&#93;</a></sup> and some practitioners and scholars refer to it as <i><a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tan%C4%AB" title="Sanātanī">Sanātana Dharma</a></i>, "the eternal tradition", or the "eternal way", beyond human history.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnott19985,_Quote:_&quot;Many_describe_Hinduism_as_&#39;&#39;sanatana_dharma&#39;&#39;,_the_eternal_tradition_or_religion._This_refers_to_the_idea_that_its_origins_lie_beyond_human_history&quot;_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnott19985,_Quote:_&quot;Many_describe_Hinduism_as_&#39;&#39;sanatana_dharma&#39;&#39;,_the_eternal_tradition_or_religion._This_refers_to_the_idea_that_its_origins_lie_beyond_human_history&quot;-6">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup> Scholars regard Hinduism as a fusion<sup id="cite_ref-Lockard_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lockard-8">&#91;note 3&#93;</a></sup> or synthesis<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193-9">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel-synthesis-10">&#91;note 4&#93;</a></sup> of various Indian cultures and traditions,<sup id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel_2007_12_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel_2007_12-11">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fusion_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fusion-12">&#91;note 5&#93;</a></sup> with diverse roots<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911-13">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;note 6&#93;</a></sup> and no founder.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler19971,_7_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler19971,_7-15">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup> This "Hindu synthesis" started to develop between 500 BCE and 300 CE,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> after the end of the <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a> (1500 to 500 BCE),<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> and flourished in the <a href="/wiki/Medieval_India" title="Medieval India">medieval period</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent">decline of Buddhism in India</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995109&amp;ndash;111_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995109&amp;ndash;111-18">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> 
</p><p>Although Hinduism contains a broad range of philosophies, it is linked by shared concepts, recognisable rituals, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_cosmology" title="Hindu cosmology">cosmology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_texts" title="Hindu texts">shared textual resources</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_pilgrimage_sites" title="Hindu pilgrimage sites">pilgrimage to sacred sites</a>. <a href="/wiki/Hindu_texts" title="Hindu texts">Hindu texts</a> are classified into <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Aruti" title="Śruti">Śruti</a> ("heard") and <a href="/wiki/Smriti" title="Smriti">Smṛti</a> ("remembered"). These texts discuss theology, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_philosophy" title="Hindu philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_mythology" title="Hindu mythology">mythology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedic</a> <a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">yajna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Hinduism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Āgama (Hinduism)">agamic</a> <a href="/wiki/Ritual" title="Ritual">rituals</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">temple building</a>, among other topics.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-19">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> Major scriptures include the <i><a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></i>, and the <a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Hinduism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Āgama (Hinduism)">Āgamas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:0_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-21">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup> Sources of authority and eternal truths in its texts play an important role, but there is also a strong Hindu tradition of questioning authority in order to deepen the understanding of these truths and to further develop the tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-frazierintrop2_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazierintrop2-22">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include the four <a href="/wiki/Puru%E1%B9%A3%C4%81rtha" title="Puruṣārtha">Puruṣārthas</a>, the proper goals or aims of human life, namely <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a> (ethics/duties), <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a> (prosperity/work), <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kama</a> (desires/passions) and <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a> (liberation/freedom from the cycle of death and <a href="/wiki/Reincarnation" title="Reincarnation">rebirth</a>/salvation);<sup id="cite_ref-Bilimoria_2007_p._103_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bilimoria_2007_p._103-23">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gavin_Flood_1997_pages_11_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gavin_Flood_1997_pages_11-24">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a> (action, intent and consequences), <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra" title="Saṃsāra">Saṃsāra</a> (cycle of death and rebirth), and the various Yogas (paths or practices to attain moksha).<sup id="cite_ref-:0_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-21">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003-25">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> Hindu practices include rituals such as <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">puja</a> (worship) and recitations, <a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">japa</a>, meditation, family-oriented <a href="/wiki/Sanskara_(rite_of_passage)" title="Sanskara (rite of passage)">rites of passage</a>, annual festivals, and occasional pilgrimages. Some Hindus leave their social world and material possessions, then engage in lifelong <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sannyasa</a> (monastic practices) to achieve Moksha.<sup id="cite_ref-ellinger70_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ellinger70-26">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> Hinduism prescribes the eternal duties, such as honesty, refraining from injuring living beings (<a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a>), patience, forbearance, self-restraint, and compassion, among others.<sup id="cite_ref-EB-sanatana_dharma_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB-sanatana_dharma-27">&#91;web 1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup> The four largest <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">denominations</a> of Hinduism are the <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Smarta_Tradition" class="mw-redirect" title="Smarta Tradition">Smartism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Hinduism is the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's third largest religion</a>; its followers, known as <a href="/wiki/Hindu" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu">Hindus</a>, constitute about <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">1.15 billion</a>, or 15–16% of the global population.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">&#91;web 2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gordonconwell.edu_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gordonconwell.edu-31">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> Hinduism is the most widely professed faith in <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_India" title="Religion in India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Nepal" title="Religion in Nepal">Nepal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Mauritius" title="Religion in Mauritius">Mauritius</a>. It is also the predominant religion in <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup> Significant numbers of Hindu communities are also found in the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>, <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">other countries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
