<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Hindu" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu">Hindu</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bratan_Bali_Indonesia_Balinese-family-after-Puja-01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Bratan_Bali_Indonesia_Balinese-family-after-Puja-01.jpg/220px-Bratan_Bali_Indonesia_Balinese-family-after-Puja-01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Bratan_Bali_Indonesia_Balinese-family-after-Puja-01.jpg/330px-Bratan_Bali_Indonesia_Balinese-family-after-Puja-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Bratan_Bali_Indonesia_Balinese-family-after-Puja-01.jpg/440px-Bratan_Bali_Indonesia_Balinese-family-after-Puja-01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4695" data-file-height="3756" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bratan_Bali_Indonesia_Balinese-family-after-Puja-01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Balinese_people" title="Balinese people">Balinese</a> <a href="/wiki/Bali_Hinduism" class="mw-redirect" title="Bali Hinduism">Hindu</a> family after <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">puja</a> at <a href="/wiki/Pura_Ulun_Danu_Bratan" title="Pura Ulun Danu Bratan">Bratan temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The word <i>Hindū</i> is derived from <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood20083_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood20083-35">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup>/<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-36">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> root <i>Sindhu</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-36">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParpola,_The_Roots_of_Hinduism2015Chapter_1_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParpola,_The_Roots_of_Hinduism2015Chapter_1-37">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Proto-Iranian_language" title="Proto-Iranian language">Proto-Iranian</a> sound change <i>*s</i> &gt; <i>h</i> occurred between 850–600 BCE, according to <a href="/wiki/Asko_Parpola" title="Asko Parpola">Asko Parpola</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParpola,_The_Roots_of_Hinduism2015Chapter_9_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParpola,_The_Roots_of_Hinduism2015Chapter_9-38">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The use of the term Hinduism to describe a collection of practices and beliefs is a recent European construction, the term "Hindu" was coined in position to other religions and used to describe those that were not of the other religions. Before the British began to categorise communities strictly by religion, Indians generally did not define themselves exclusively through their religious beliefs; identities were segmented on the basis of locality, language, caste, occupation and sect.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-39">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>It is believed that <i>Hindu</i> was used as the name for the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a> in the northwestern part of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> (modern day Pakistan and <a href="/wiki/Northern_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern India">Northern India</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_36-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-36">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;note 7&#93;</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Gavin_Flood" title="Gavin Flood">Gavin Flood</a>, "The actual term <i>Hindu</i> first occurs as a <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> geographical term for the people who lived beyond the river Indus (Sanskrit: <i>Sindhu</i>)",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_36-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-36">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> more specifically in the 6th-century BCE inscription of <a href="/wiki/Darius_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Darius I">Darius I</a> (550–486 BCE).<sup id="cite_ref-arvindsharmahhhh2_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arvindsharmahhhh2-41">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> The term <i>Hindu</i> in these ancient records is a geographical term and did not refer to a religion.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_36-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-36">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> Among the earliest known records of 'Hindu' with connotations of religion may be in the 7th-century CE Chinese text <i>Record of the Western Regions</i> by <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-arvindsharmahhhh2_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arvindsharmahhhh2-41">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup> and 14th-century Persian text <i>Futuhu's-salatin</i> by 'Abd al-Malik <a href="/wiki/Isami_(historian)" class="mw-redirect" title="Isami (historian)">Isami</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;note 8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Thapar states that the word <i>Hindu</i> is found as <i>heptahindu</i> in <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a> – equivalent to Rigvedic <i>sapta sindhu</i>, while <i>hndstn</i> (pronounced <i>Hindustan</i>) is found in a <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian</a> inscription from the 3rd century CE, both of which refer to parts of northwestern South Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> The Arabic term <i>al-Hind</i> referred to the people who live across the River Indus.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThapar199377_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar199377-50">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> This Arabic term was itself taken from the pre-Islamic Persian term <i>Hindū</i>, which refers to all Indians. By the 13th century, <i><a href="/wiki/Hindustan" title="Hindustan">Hindustan</a></i> emerged as a popular alternative <a href="/wiki/Names_of_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Names of India">name of India</a>, meaning the "land of Hindus".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThompson_Platts1884_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThompson_Platts1884-51">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;note 9&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The term <i>Hindu</i> was later used occasionally in some Sanskrit texts such as the later <i><a href="/wiki/Rajatarangini" title="Rajatarangini">Rajataranginis</a></i> of Kashmir (Hinduka, c. 1450) and some 16th- to 18th-century <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a> <a href="/wiki/Gaudiya_Vaishnavism" title="Gaudiya Vaishnavism">Gaudiya Vaishnava</a> texts including <i><a href="/wiki/Chaitanya_Charitamrita" title="Chaitanya Charitamrita">Chaitanya Charitamrita</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Chaitanya_Bhagavata" title="Chaitanya Bhagavata">Chaitanya Bhagavata</a></i>. These texts used it to distinguish Hindus from Muslims who are called <a href="/wiki/Yona#Later_meanings" title="Yona">Yavanas</a> (foreigners) or <a href="/wiki/Mleccha" title="Mleccha">Mlecchas</a> (barbarians), with the 16th-century <i>Chaitanya Charitamrita</i> text and the 17th-century <i>Bhakta Mala</i> text using the phrase "<i>Hindu dharma</i>".<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> It was only towards the end of the 18th century that European merchants and colonists began to refer to the followers of Indian religions collectively as <i>Hindus</i>.
</p><p>The term <i>Hinduism</i>, then spelled <i>Hindooism</i>, was introduced into the English language in the 18th century to denote the religious, philosophical, and cultural traditions native to India.<sup id="cite_ref-Sweetman2003_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sweetman2003-54">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Definitions">Definitions</span></h2>
<p>Hinduism includes a diversity of ideas on <a href="/wiki/Spirituality#Hinduism" title="Spirituality">spirituality</a> and traditions, but has no ecclesiastical order, no unquestionable religious authorities, no governing body, no prophet(s) nor any binding holy book; Hindus can choose to be polytheistic, pantheistic, panentheistic, pandeistic, henotheistic, monotheistic, monistic, agnostic, atheistic or humanist.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup> Ideas about all the major issues of faith and lifestyle including: vegetarianism, nonviolence, belief in rebirth, even caste, are subjects of debate, not dogma.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-39">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of the wide range of traditions and ideas covered by the term Hinduism, arriving at a comprehensive definition is difficult.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_36-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-36">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> The religion "defies our desire to define and categorize it".<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> Hinduism has been variously defined as a religion, a religious tradition, a set of religious beliefs, and "a way of life".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200312-13_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200312-13-59">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-definition_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-definition-1">&#91;note 1&#93;</a></sup> From a Western lexical standpoint, Hinduism like other faiths is appropriately referred to as a religion. In India the term <i>dharma</i> is preferred, which is broader than the Western term <i>religion</i>.
</p><p>The study of India and its cultures and religions, and the definition of "Hinduism", has been shaped by the interests of colonialism and by Western notions of religion.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> Since the 1990s, those influences and its outcomes have been the topic of debate among scholars of Hinduism,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman2004_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman2004-61">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">&#91;note 10&#93;</a></sup> and have also been taken over by critics of the Western view on India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENussbaum2009_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENussbaum2009-63">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;note 11&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Typology">Typology</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">Hindu denominations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg/220px-Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="218" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg/330px-Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg/440px-Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="507" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Om" title="Om">AUM</a>, a stylised letter of <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a> script, used as a religious symbol in Hinduism</div></div></div>
<p>Hinduism as it is commonly known can be subdivided into a number of major currents. Of the historical division into six <a href="/wiki/Darsanas" class="mw-redirect" title="Darsanas">darsanas</a> (philosophies), two schools, <a href="/wiki/Vedanta" title="Vedanta">Vedanta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yoga_(philosophy)" title="Yoga (philosophy)">Yoga</a>, are currently the most prominent.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> Classified by primary deity or deities, four major Hinduism modern currents are <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> (Vishnu), <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> (Shiva), <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> (Devi) and <a href="/wiki/Smarta_Tradition" class="mw-redirect" title="Smarta Tradition">Smartism</a> (five deities treated as same).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENath200131_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENath200131-66">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_154_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_154-67">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup> Hinduism also accepts numerous divine beings, with many Hindus considering the deities to be aspects or manifestations of a single impersonal absolute or ultimate reality or God, while some Hindus maintain that a specific deity represents the supreme and various deities are lower manifestations of this supreme.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199614_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199614-68">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> Other notable characteristics include a belief in existence of <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">ātman</a> (soul, self), <a href="/wiki/Reincarnation" title="Reincarnation">reincarnation</a> of one's ātman, and karma as well as a belief in dharma (duties, rights, laws, conduct, virtues and right way of living).
</p><p>McDaniel (2007) classifies Hinduism into six major kinds and numerous minor kinds, in order to understand expression of emotions among the Hindus.<sup id="cite_ref-junemcdaniel6_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-junemcdaniel6-69">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> The major kinds, according to McDaniel are, <a href="/wiki/Folk_Hinduism" class="mw-redirect" title="Folk Hinduism">Folk Hinduism</a>, based on local traditions and cults of local <a href="/wiki/Deities" class="mw-redirect" title="Deities">deities</a> and is the oldest, non-literate system; <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Vedic Hinduism</a> based on the earliest layers of the Vedas traceable to 2nd millennium BCE; Vedantic Hinduism based on the philosophy of the <a href="/wiki/Upanishad" class="mw-redirect" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>, emphasizing knowledge and wisdom; Yogic Hinduism, following the text of <a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras_of_Patanjali" title="Yoga Sutras of Patanjali">Yoga Sutras of Patanjali</a> emphasizing introspective awareness; Dharmic Hinduism or "daily morality", which McDaniel states is stereotyped in some books as the "only form of Hindu religion with a belief in karma, cows and caste"; and <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">Bhakti</a> or devotional Hinduism, where intense emotions are elaborately incorporated in the pursuit of the spiritual.<sup id="cite_ref-junemcdaniel6_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-junemcdaniel6-69">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Michaels distinguishes three Hindu religions and four forms of Hindu religiosity.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421-70">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> The three Hindu religions are "Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism", "folk religions and tribal religions", and "founded religions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422-71">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> The four forms of Hindu religiosity are the classical "karma-marga",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423-72">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jnana_yoga" title="Jnana yoga">jnana-marga</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424-73">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_yoga" title="Bhakti yoga">bhakti-marga</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424-73">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> and "heroism", which is rooted in <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa#Warrior_ascetics" title="Sannyasa">militaristic traditions</a>, such as Ramaism and parts of political Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423-72">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> This is also called <a href="/wiki/V%C4%ABrya_(Hinduism)" title="Vīrya (Hinduism)">virya-marga</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424_73-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424-73">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> According to Michaels, one out of nine Hindu belongs by birth to one or both of the Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism and Folk religion typology, whether practicing or non-practicing. He classifies most Hindus as belonging by choice to one of the "founded religions" such as Vaishnavism and Shaivism that are salvation-focussed and often de-emphasize Brahman priestly authority yet incorporate ritual grammar of Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421–22_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421–22-74">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> He includes among "founded religions" Buddhism, Jainism, Sikhism that are now distinct religions, syncretic movements such as <a href="/wiki/Brahmo_Samaj" title="Brahmo Samaj">Brahmo Samaj</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Theosophical_Society" title="Theosophical Society">Theosophical Society</a>, as well as various "Guru-isms" and new religious movements such as <a href="/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi" title="Maharishi Mahesh Yogi">Maharishi Mahesh Yogi</a> and <a href="/wiki/ISKCON" class="mw-redirect" title="ISKCON">ISKCON</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422–23_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422–23-75">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Inden states that the attempt to classify Hinduism by typology started in the imperial times, when proselytizing missionaries and colonial officials sought to understand and portray Hinduism from their interests.<sup id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-76">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> Hinduism was construed as emanating not from a reason of spirit but fantasy and creative imagination, not conceptual but symbolical, not ethical but emotive, not rational or spiritual but of cognitive mysticism. This stereotype followed and fit, states Inden, with the imperial imperatives of the era, providing the moral justification for the colonial project.<sup id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_76-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-76">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> From tribal Animism to Buddhism, everything was subsumed as part of Hinduism. The early reports set the tradition and scholarly premises for typology of Hinduism, as well as the major assumptions and flawed presuppositions that has been at the foundation of Indology. Hinduism, according to Inden, has been neither what imperial religionists stereotyped it to be, nor is it appropriate to equate Hinduism to be merely monist pantheism and philosophical idealism of Advaita Vedanta.<sup id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_76-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-76">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_understanding">Indigenous understanding</span></h3>
<h4><span id="San.C4.81tana_Dharma"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Sanātana_Dharma"><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">Sanātana Dharma</i></span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tan%C4%AB" title="Sanātanī">Sanātanī</a></div>
<p>To its adherents, Hinduism is a traditional way of life.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup> Many practitioners refer to the "orthodox" form of Hinduism as <i><a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tan%C4%AB" title="Sanātanī"><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">Sanātana Dharma</i></a></i>, "the eternal law" or the "eternal way".<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVivekjivandas20101_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVivekjivandas20101-79">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> word <i>dharma</i> has a much broader meaning than <i><a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">religion</a></i> and is not its equivalent. All aspects of a Hindu life, namely acquiring wealth (artha), fulfillment of desires (kama), and attaining liberation (moksha) are part of dharma which encapsulates the "right way of living" and eternal harmonious principles in their fulfillment.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the editors of the Encyclopædia Britannica, <i><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">Sanātana Dharma</i></i> historically referred to the "eternal" duties religiously ordained in Hinduism, duties such as honesty, refraining from injuring living beings (<i><a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a></i>), purity, goodwill, mercy, patience, forbearance, self-restraint, generosity, and asceticism. These duties applied regardless of a Hindu's class, caste, or sect, and they contrasted with <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita#Svadharma_and_svabhava" title="Bhagavad Gita">svadharma</a>, one's "own duty", in accordance with one's class or caste (<a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">varna</a>) and stage in life (<a href="/wiki/Puru%E1%B9%A3%C4%81rtha" title="Puruṣārtha">puruṣārtha</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-EB-sanatana_dharma_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB-sanatana_dharma-27">&#91;web 1&#93;</a></sup> In recent years, the term has been used by Hindu leaders, reformers, and nationalists to refer to Hinduism. Sanatana dharma has become a synonym for the "eternal" truth and teachings of Hinduism, that transcend history and are "unchanging, indivisible and ultimately nonsectarian".<sup id="cite_ref-EB-sanatana_dharma_27-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB-sanatana_dharma-27">&#91;web 1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to other scholars such as Kim Knott and Brian Hatcher, Sanātana Dharma refers to "timeless, eternal set of truths" and this is how Hindus view the origins of their religion. It is viewed as those eternal truths and tradition with origins beyond human history, truths divinely revealed (<a href="/wiki/Shruti" class="mw-redirect" title="Shruti">Shruti</a>) in the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a> – the most ancient of the world's scriptures.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hatcher2015p4_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hatcher2015p4-83">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> To many Hindus, the Western term "religion" to the extent it means "dogma and an institution traceable to a single founder" is inappropriate for their tradition, states Hatcher. Hinduism, to them, is a tradition that can be traced at least to the ancient Vedic era.<sup id="cite_ref-Hatcher2015p4_83-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hatcher2015p4-83">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lipner2012p15_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lipner2012p15-84">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">&#91;note 12&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vaidika_dharma"><i>Vaidika dharma</i></span></h4>
<p>Some have referred to Hinduism as the <i>Vaidika dharma</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> The word 'Vaidika' in Sanskrit means 'derived from or conformable to the Veda' or 'relating to the Veda'.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup> Traditional scholars employed the terms Vaidika and Avaidika, those who accept the Vedas as a source of authoritative knowledge and those who don't, to differentiate various Indian schools from Jainism, Buddhism and Charvaka. According to Klaus Klostermaier, the term Vaidika dharma is the earliest self-designation of Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Arvind_Sharma" title="Arvind Sharma">Arvind Sharma</a>, the historical evidence suggests that "the Hindus were referring to their religion by the term <i>vaidika dharma</i> or a variant thereof" by the 4th-century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> According to Brian K. Smith "[i]t is 'debatable at the very least' as to whether the term <i>Vaidika Dharma</i> cannot, with the proper concessions to historical, cultural and ideological specificity, be comparable to and translated as 'Hinduism' or 'Hindu religion'."<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Alexis Sanderson, the early Sanskrit texts differentiate between Vaidika, Vaishnava, Shaiva, Shakta, Saura, Buddhist and Jaina traditions. However, the late 1st-millennium CE Indic consensus had "indeed come to conceptualize a complex entity corresponding to Hinduism as opposed to Buddhism and Jainism excluding only certain forms of antinomian Shakta-Shaiva" from its fold.<sup id="cite_ref-sandersonpart1_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart1-93">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> Some in the <a href="/wiki/Mimamsa" class="mw-redirect" title="Mimamsa">Mimamsa</a> school of Hindu philosophy considered the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Hinduism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Āgama (Hinduism)">Agamas</a></i> such as the Pancaratrika to be invalid because it did not conform to the Vedas. Some Kashmiri scholars rejected the esoteric tantric traditions to be a part of Vaidika dharma.<sup id="cite_ref-sandersonpart1_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart1-93">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> The Atimarga Shaivism ascetic tradition, datable to about 500 CE, challenged the Vaidika frame and insisted that their Agamas and practices were not only valid, they were superior than those of the Vaidikas.<sup id="cite_ref-sandersonpart3_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart3-95">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup> However, adds Sanderson, this Shaiva ascetic tradition viewed themselves as being genuinely true to the Vedic tradition and "held unanimously that the Śruti and Smṛti of Brahmanism are universally and uniquely valid in their own sphere, [...] and that as such they [Vedas] are man's sole means of valid knowledge [...]".<sup id="cite_ref-sandersonpart3_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart3-95">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The term Vaidika dharma means a code of practice that is "based on the Vedas", but it is unclear what "based on the Vedas" really implies, states Julius Lipner.<sup id="cite_ref-Lipner2012p15_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lipner2012p15-84">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> The Vaidika dharma or "Vedic way of life", states Lipner, does not mean "Hinduism is necessarily religious" or that Hindus have a universally accepted "conventional or institutional meaning" for that term.<sup id="cite_ref-Lipner2012p15_84-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lipner2012p15-84">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> To many, it is as much a cultural term. Many Hindus do not have a copy of the Vedas nor have they ever seen or personally read parts of a Veda, like a Christian might relate to the Bible or a Muslim might to the Quran. Yet, states Lipner, "this does not mean that their [Hindus] whole life's orientation cannot be traced to the Vedas or that it does not in some way derive from it".<sup id="cite_ref-Lipner2012p15_84-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lipner2012p15-84">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Many religious Hindus implicitly acknowledge the authority of the Vedas, this acknowledgment is often "no more than a declaration that someone considers himself [or herself] a Hindu." Some Hindus challenge the authority of the Vedas, thereby implicitly acknowledging its importance to the history of Hinduism, states Lipner.<sup id="cite_ref-Lipner2012p15_84-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lipner2012p15-84">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindu_modernism">Hindu modernism</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg/220px-Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="302" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg/330px-Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg/440px-Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg 2x" data-file-width="933" data-file-height="1280" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda" title="Swami Vivekananda">Swami Vivekananda</a> was a key figure in introducing Vedanta and Yoga in Europe and the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFeuerstein2002600_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFeuerstein2002600-96">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> raising interfaith awareness and making Hinduism a world religion.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClarke2006209_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClarke2006209-97">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_reform_movements" title="Hindu reform movements">Hindu reform movements</a></div>
<p>Beginning in the 19th century, Indian modernists re-asserted Hinduism as a major asset of Indian civilisation,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-98">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> meanwhile "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233-99">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> and elevating the Vedic elements. Western stereotypes were reversed, emphasizing the universal aspects, and introducing modern approaches of social problems.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-98">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> This approach had a great appeal, not only in India, but also in the west.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_98-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-98">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> Major representatives of <a href="/wiki/Neo-Vedanta" title="Neo-Vedanta">"Hindu modernism"</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-100">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> are <a href="/wiki/Raja_Rammohan_Roy" class="mw-redirect" title="Raja Rammohan Roy">Raja Rammohan Roy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vivekananda" class="mw-redirect" title="Vivekananda">Vivekananda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarvepalli_Radhakrishnan" title="Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan">Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996256-261_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996256-261-101">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Raja_Rammohan_Roy" class="mw-redirect" title="Raja Rammohan Roy">Raja Rammohan Roy</a> is known as the father of the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Renaissance" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu Renaissance">Hindu Renaissance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hindu1_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hindu1-102">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> He was a major influence on Swami Vivekananda (1863–1902), who, according to Flood, was "a figure of great importance in the development of a modern Hindu self-understanding and in formulating the West's view of Hinduism".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996257_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996257-103">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> Central to his philosophy is the idea that the divine exists in all beings, that all human beings can achieve union with this "innate divinity",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_100-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-100">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> and that seeing this divine as the essence of others will further love and social harmony.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_100-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-100">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> According to Vivekananda, there is an essential unity to Hinduism, which underlies the diversity of its many forms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_100-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-100">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup> According to Flood, Vivekananda's vision of Hinduism "is one generally accepted by most English-speaking middle-class Hindus today".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996259_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996259-104">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup> Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan sought to reconcile western rationalism with Hinduism, "presenting Hinduism as an essentially rationalistic and humanistic religious experience".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996249_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996249-105">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>This "Global Hinduism"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-106">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> has a worldwide appeal, transcending national boundaries<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_106-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-106">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> and, according to Flood, "becoming a world religion alongside Christianity, Islam and Buddhism",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_106-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-106">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> both for the Hindu diaspora communities and for westerners who are attracted to non-western cultures and religions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_106-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-106">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> It emphasizes universal spiritual values such as social justice, peace and "the spiritual transformation of humanity".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_106-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-106">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> It has developed partly due to "re-enculturation",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-107">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> or the <a href="/wiki/Pizza_effect" title="Pizza effect">Pizza effect</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-107">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> in which elements of Hindu culture have been exported to the West, gaining popularity there, and as a consequence also gained greater popularity in India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267_107-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-107">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> This globalization of Hindu culture brought "to the West teachings which have become an important cultural force in western societies, and which in turn have become an important cultural force in India, their place of origin".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-268_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-268-108">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_Definitions">Legal Definitions</span></h4>
<p>The definition of Hinduism in Indian Law  is: "Acceptance of the Vedas with reverence; recognition of the fact that the means or ways to salvation are diverse; and realization of the truth that the number of gods to be worshipped is large"<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_39-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-39">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Western_understanding">Western understanding</span></h3>
<p>The term <i>Hinduism</i> is coined in Western ethnography in the 18th century,<sup id="cite_ref-Sweetman2003_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sweetman2003-54">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> and refers to the fusion<sup id="cite_ref-Lockard_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lockard-8">&#91;note 3&#93;</a></sup> or synthesis<sup id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel-synthesis-10">&#91;note 4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193-9">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup> of various Indian cultures and traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel_2007_12_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel_2007_12-11">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fusion_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fusion-12">&#91;note 5&#93;</a></sup> which emerged after the Vedic period, between 500<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>-200<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> BCE and c. 300 CE,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> the beginning of the "Epic and Puranic" c.q. "Preclassical" period.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Hinduism's tolerance to variations in belief and its broad range of traditions make it difficult to define as a religion according to traditional Western conceptions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1996-A275_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1996-A275-116">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Some academics suggest that Hinduism can be seen as a category with "fuzzy edges" rather than as a well-defined and rigid entity. Some forms of religious expression are central to Hinduism and others, while not as central, still remain within the category. Based on this idea Ferro-Luzzi has developed a 'Prototype Theory approach' to the definition of Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Diversity_and_unity">Diversity and unity</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diversity">Diversity</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">Hindu denominations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ganapati.1..JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Ganapati.1..JPG/220px-Ganapati.1..JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Ganapati.1..JPG/330px-Ganapati.1..JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Ganapati.1..JPG/440px-Ganapati.1..JPG 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ganapati.1..JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> is one of the best-known and most worshipped deities in the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_deities" title="Hindu deities">Hindu pantheon</a></div></div></div>
<p>Hinduism has been described as a tradition having a "complex, organic, multileveled and sometimes internally inconsistent nature".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger2000434_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger2000434-118">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> Hinduism does not have a "unified system of belief encoded in a declaration of faith or a <a href="/wiki/Creed" title="Creed">creed</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_36-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-36">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> but is rather an umbrella term comprising the plurality of religious phenomena of India.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup> According to the Supreme Court of India,
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047036">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Unlike other religions in the World, the Hindu religion does not claim any one Prophet, it does not worship any one God, it does not believe in any one philosophic concept, it does not follow any one act of religious rites or performances; in fact, it does not satisfy the traditional features of a religion or creed. It is a way of life and nothing more".<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<p>Part of the problem with a single definition of the term <i>Hinduism</i> is the fact that Hinduism does not have a founder.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup> It is a synthesis of various traditions,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup> the "Brahmanical orthopraxy, the renouncer traditions and popular or local traditions".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199616_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199616-113">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Theism" title="Theism">Theism</a> is also difficult to use as a unifying doctrine for Hinduism, because while some Hindu philosophies postulate a <a href="/wiki/Theism" title="Theism">theistic</a> <a href="/wiki/Ontology" title="Ontology">ontology</a> of creation, other <a href="/wiki/Atheism_in_Hinduism" title="Atheism in Hinduism">Hindus are or have been atheists</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sense_of_unity">Sense of unity</span></h3>
<p>Despite the differences, there is also a sense of unity.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-123">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> Most Hindu traditions revere a body of religious or <a href="/wiki/Sastra" class="mw-redirect" title="Sastra">sacred literature</a>, the Vedas,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson2010_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson2010-124">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> although there are exceptions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199635_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199635-125">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> These texts are a reminder of the ancient cultural heritage and point of pride for Hindus,<sup id="cite_ref-andreapinkney_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-andreapinkney-126">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Louis_Renou" title="Louis Renou">Louis Renou</a> stating that "even in the most orthodox domains, the reverence to the Vedas has come to be a simple raising of the hat".<sup id="cite_ref-andreapinkney_126-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-andreapinkney-126">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass19911_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass19911-128">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Halbfass states that, although Shaivism and Vaishaism may be regarded as "self-contained religious constellations",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_123-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-123">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> there is a degree of interaction and reference between the "theoreticians and literary representatives"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_123-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-123">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> of each tradition which indicates the presence of "a wider sense of identity, a sense of coherence in a shared context and of inclusion in a common framework and horizon".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_123-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-123">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Indigenous_developments">Indigenous developments</span></h4>
<p>The notion of common denominators for several religions and traditions of India further developed from the 12th century CE on.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup> Lorenzen traces the emergence of a "family resemblance", and what he calls as "beginnings of medieval and modern Hinduism" taking shape, at c. 300–600 CE, with the development of the early Puranas, and continuities with the earlier Vedic religion.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636-130">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> Lorenzen states that the establishment of a Hindu self-identity took place "through a process of mutual self-definition with a contrasting Muslim Other".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648-131">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> According to Lorenzen, this "presence of the Other"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648-131">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> is necessary to recognise the "loose family resemblance" among the various traditions and schools,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648,655_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648,655-132">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the Indologist <a href="/wiki/Alexis_Sanderson" title="Alexis Sanderson">Alexis Sanderson</a>, before Islam arrived in India, the "Sanskrit sources differentiated Vaidika, Vaiṣṇava, Śaiva, Śākta, Saura, Buddhist, and Jaina traditions, but they had no name that denotes the first five of these as a collective entity over and against Buddhism and Jainism." This absence of a formal name, states Sanderson, does not mean that the corresponding concept of Hinduism did not exist. By late 1st-millennium CE, the concept of a belief and tradition distinct from Buddhism and Jainism had emerged.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanderson2015_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanderson2015-133">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> This complex tradition accepted in its identity almost all of what is currently Hinduism, except certain antinomian tantric movements.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanderson2015_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanderson2015-133">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> Some conservative thinkers of those times questioned whether certain Shaiva, Vaishnava and Shakta texts or practices were consistent with the Vedas, or were invalid in their entirety. Moderates then, and most orthoprax scholars later, agreed that though there are some variations, the foundation of their beliefs, the ritual grammar, the spiritual premises and the soteriologies were same. "This sense of greater unity", states Sanderson, "came to be called Hinduism".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESanderson2015_133-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESanderson2015-133">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Nicholson, already between the 12th and the 16th centuries "certain thinkers began to treat as a single whole the diverse philosophical teachings of the Upanishads, epics, Puranas, and the schools known retrospectively as the 'six systems' (<i>saddarsana</i>) of mainstream Hindu philosophy."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson20102_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson20102-134">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> The tendency of "a blurring of philosophical distinctions" has also been noted by Burley.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurley200734_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurley200734-135">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> Hacker called this "inclusivism"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson2010_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson2010-124">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> and Michaels speaks of "the identificatory habit".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-19">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> Lorenzen locates the origins of a distinct Hindu identity in the interaction between Muslims and Hindus,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200624-33_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200624-33-136">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup> and a process of "mutual self-definition with a contrasting Muslim other",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200627_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200627-137">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;note 13&#93;</a></sup> which started well before 1800.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200626-27_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200626-27-139">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup> Michaels notes:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>As a counteraction to Islamic supremacy and as part of the continuing process of regionalization, two religious innovations developed in the Hindu religions: the formation of sects and a historicization which preceded later nationalism [...] [S]aints and sometimes militant sect leaders, such as the Marathi poet Tukaram (1609–1649) and Ramdas (1608–1681), articulated ideas in which they glorified Hinduism and the past. The Brahmins also produced increasingly historical texts, especially eulogies and chronicles of sacred sites (Mahatmyas), or developed a reflexive passion for collecting and compiling extensive collections of quotations on various subjects.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444-140">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<p>This inclusivism<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> was further developed in the 19th and 20th centuries by <a href="/wiki/Hindu_reform_movements" title="Hindu reform movements">Hindu reform movements</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neo-Vedanta" title="Neo-Vedanta">Neo-Vedanta</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2001_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2001-142">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup> and has become characteristic of modern Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson2010_124-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson2010-124">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_influences">Colonial influences</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Orientalism" title="Orientalism">Orientalism</a></div>
<p>The notion and reports on "Hinduism" as a "single world religious tradition"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999100–102_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999100–102-143">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> was popularised by 19th-century proselytizing missionaries and European Indologists, roles sometimes served by the same person, who relied on texts preserved by Brahmins (priests) for their information of Indian religions, and animist observations which the missionary Orientalists presumed was Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999100–102_143-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999100–102-143">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_76-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-76">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200414–15_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200414–15-144">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> These reports influenced perceptions about Hinduism. Some scholars<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words"><span title="Who says this? (April 2017)">weasel&#160;words</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> state that the colonial polemical reports led to fabricated stereotypes where Hinduism was mere mystic paganism devoted to the service of devils,<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;note 14&#93;</a></sup> while other scholars state that the colonial constructions influenced the belief that the <i>Vedas</i>, <i>Bhagavad Gita</i>, <i>Manusmriti</i> and such texts were the essence of Hindu religiosity, and in the modern association of 'Hindu doctrine' with the schools of Vedanta (in particular Advaita Vedanta) as paradigmatic example of Hinduism's mystical nature".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999169_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999169-147">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;note 15&#93;</a></sup> Pennington, while concurring that the study of Hinduism as a world religion began in the colonial era, disagrees that Hinduism is a colonial European era invention.<sup id="cite_ref-brianpennington5_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brianpennington5-158">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> He states that the shared theology, common ritual grammar and way of life of those who identify themselves as Hindus is traceable to ancient times.<sup id="cite_ref-brianpennington5_158-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brianpennington5-158">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;note 16&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Beliefs">Beliefs</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Halebid3.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Halebid3.JPG/200px-Halebid3.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Halebid3.JPG/300px-Halebid3.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Halebid3.JPG/400px-Halebid3.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Halebid3.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Temple wall panel relief sculpture at the <a href="/wiki/Hoysaleswara_temple" class="mw-redirect" title="Hoysaleswara temple">Hoysaleswara temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/Halebidu" class="mw-redirect" title="Halebidu">Halebidu</a>, representing the <a href="/wiki/Trimurti" title="Trimurti">Trimurti</a>: <a href="/wiki/Brahma" title="Brahma">Brahma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a></div></div></div>
<p>Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include (but are not restricted to) Dharma (ethics/duties), <a href="/wiki/Samsara" class="mw-redirect" title="Samsara"><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">Samsāra</i></a> (the continuing cycle of birth, life, death and rebirth), Karma (action, intent and consequences), Moksha (liberation from samsara or liberation in this life), and the various Yogas (paths or practices).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003-25">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Purusharthas_.28objectives_of_human_life.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Purusharthas_(objectives_of_human_life)">Purusharthas (objectives of human life)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Purusharthas" class="mw-redirect" title="Purusharthas">Purusharthas</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Initiation_in_Hinduism" class="mw-redirect" title="Initiation in Hinduism">Initiation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kāma</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Moksha#Hinduism" title="Moksha">Mokṣa</a></div>
<p>Classical Hindu thought accepts four proper goals or aims of human life: <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kama</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a>. These are known as the <a href="/wiki/Puru%E1%B9%A3%C4%81rtha" title="Puruṣārtha">Puruṣārthas</a>:<sup id="cite_ref-Bilimoria_2007_p._103_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bilimoria_2007_p._103-23">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gavin_Flood_1997_pages_11_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gavin_Flood_1997_pages_11-24">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Dharma_.28righteousness.2C_ethics.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Dharma_(righteousness,_ethics)">Dharma (righteousness, ethics)</span></h4>
<p>Dharma is considered the foremost goal of a human being in Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> The concept Dharma includes behaviors that are considered to be in accord with <a href="/wiki/Rta" class="mw-redirect" title="Rta">rta</a>, the order that makes life and universe possible,<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> and includes duties, rights, laws, conduct, virtues and "right way of living".<sup id="cite_ref-tce_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tce-168">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup> Hindu Dharma includes the religious duties, moral rights and duties of each individual, as well as behaviors that enable social order, right conduct, and those that are virtuous.<sup id="cite_ref-tce_168-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tce-168">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup> Dharma, according to <a href="/wiki/J._A._B._van_Buitenen" title="J. A. B. van Buitenen">Van Buitenen</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-vanbuitenen_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vanbuitenen-169">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> is that which all existing beings must accept and respect to sustain harmony and order in the world. It is, states Van Buitenen, the pursuit and execution of one's nature and true calling, thus playing one's role in cosmic concert.<sup id="cite_ref-vanbuitenen_169-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vanbuitenen-169">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Brihadaranyaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Brihadaranyaka">Brihadaranyaka Upanishad</a> states it as:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Nothing is higher than Dharma. The weak overcomes the stronger by Dharma, as over a king. Truly that Dharma is the Truth (<i>Satya</i>); Therefore, when a man speaks the Truth, they say, "He speaks the Dharma"; and if he speaks Dharma, they say, "He speaks the Truth!" For both are one.</p><div class="templatequotecite">—&#8201;<cite><a href="/wiki/Brihadaranyaka_Upanishad" title="Brihadaranyaka Upanishad">Brihadaranyaka Upanishad</a>, 1.4.xiv <sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup></cite></div>
</blockquote>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Krishna</a> defines dharma as upholding both this-worldly and other-worldly affairs. (Mbh 12.110.11). The word <i>Sanātana</i> means <i>eternal</i>, <i>perennial</i>, or <i>forever</i>; thus, <i>Sanātana Dharma</i> signifies that it is the dharma that has neither beginning nor end.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Artha_.28livelihood.2C_wealth.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Artha_(livelihood,_wealth)">Artha (livelihood, wealth)</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a></div>
<p>Artha is objective and virtuous pursuit of wealth for livelihood, obligations and economic prosperity. It is inclusive of political life, diplomacy and material well-being. The Artha concept includes all "means of life", activities and resources that enables one to be in a state one wants to be in, wealth, career and financial security.<sup id="cite_ref-johnk_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-johnk-173">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> The proper pursuit of artha is considered an important aim of human life in Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bruces_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bruces-175">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="K.C4.81ma_.28sensual_pleasure.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Kāma_(sensual_pleasure)">Kāma (sensual pleasure)</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kama</a></div>
<p>Kāma (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a>; <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a>: काम) means desire, wish, passion, longing, pleasure of the <a href="/wiki/Senses" class="mw-redirect" title="Senses">senses</a>, the aesthetic enjoyment of life, affection, or love, with or without sexual connotations.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mmwse_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mmwse-177">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> In Hinduism, Kama is considered an essential and healthy goal of human life when pursued without sacrificing Dharma, Artha and Moksha.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Mok.E1.B9.A3a_.28liberation.2C_freedom_from_samsara.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mokṣa_(liberation,_freedom_from_samsara)">Mokṣa (liberation, freedom from samsara)</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a></div>
<p>Moksha (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: <span lang="sa" title="Sanskrit language text">मोक्ष</span> <i><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">mokṣa</i></i>) or <b>mukti</b> (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: <span lang="sa" title="Sanskrit language text">मुक्ति</span>) is the ultimate, most important goal in Hinduism. In one sense, Moksha is a concept associated with liberation from sorrow, suffering and saṃsāra (birth-rebirth cycle). A release from this eschatological cycle, in after life, particularly in theistic schools of Hinduism is called moksha.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> In other schools of Hinduism, such as monistic, moksha is a goal achievable in current life, as a state of bliss through self-realization, of comprehending the nature of one's soul, of freedom and of "realizing the whole universe as the Self".<sup id="cite_ref-E._Deutsch_pp_343-360_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-E._Deutsch_pp_343-360-181">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Karma_and_samsara">Karma and samsara</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">Karma</a></div>
<p><i>Karma</i> translates literally as <i>action</i>, <i>work</i>, or <i>deed</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> and also refers to a Vedic theory of "moral law of cause and effect".<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> The theory is a combination of (1) causality that may be ethical or non-ethical; (2) ethicization, that is good or bad actions have consequences; and (3) rebirth.<sup id="cite_ref-wdointro_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wdointro-186">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> Karma theory is interpreted as explaining the present circumstances of an individual with reference to his or her actions in the past. These actions and their consequences may be in a person's current life, or, according to some schools of Hinduism, in past lives.<sup id="cite_ref-wdointro_186-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wdointro-186">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> This cycle of birth, life, death and rebirth is called <i>samsara</i>. Liberation from samsara through moksha is believed to ensure lasting <a href="/wiki/%C4%80nanda_(Hindu_philosophy)" title="Ānanda (Hindu philosophy)">happiness</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peace#Hinduism" title="Peace">peace</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup> Hindu scriptures teach that the future is both a function of current human effort derived from free will and past human actions that set the circumstances.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Moksha">Moksha</span></h3>
<p>The ultimate goal of life, referred to as <i>moksha</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Nirvana" title="Nirvana">nirvana</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Sam%C4%81dhi" class="mw-redirect" title="Samādhi">samadhi</a></i>, is understood in several different ways: as the realization of one's union with God; as the realization of one's eternal relationship with God; realization of the unity of all existence; perfect unselfishness and knowledge of the Self; as the attainment of perfect mental peace; and as detachment from worldly desires. Such realization liberates one from samsara, thereby ending the cycle of rebirth, sorrow and suffering.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup> Due to belief in the indestructibility of the soul,<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> death is deemed insignificant with respect to the cosmic self.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The meaning of <i>moksha</i> differs among the various Hindu schools of thought. For example, Advaita Vedanta holds that after attaining moksha a person knows their "soul, self" and identifies it as one with Brahman and everyone in all respects.<sup id="cite_ref-karlpotter_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter-195">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-klausklost_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-klausklost-196">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> The followers of <a href="/wiki/Dvaita" class="mw-redirect" title="Dvaita">Dvaita</a> (dualistic) schools, in moksha state, identify individual "soul, self" as distinct from Brahman but infinitesimally close, and after attaining moksha expect to spend eternity in a <a href="/wiki/Loka" title="Loka">loka</a> (heaven). To theistic schools of Hinduism, moksha is liberation from samsara, while for other schools such as the monistic school, moksha is possible in current life and is a psychological concept. According to Deutsche, moksha is transcendental consciousness to the latter, the perfect state of being, of self-realization, of freedom and of "realizing the whole universe as the Self".<sup id="cite_ref-E._Deutsch_pp_343-360_181-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-E._Deutsch_pp_343-360-181">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-karlpotter_195-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter-195">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> <i>Moksha</i> in these schools of Hinduism, suggests <a href="/wiki/Klaus_Klostermaier" title="Klaus Klostermaier">Klaus Klostermaier</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-klausklost_196-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-klausklost-196">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> implies a setting free of hitherto fettered faculties, a removing of obstacles to an unrestricted life, permitting a person to be more truly a person in the full sense; the concept presumes an unused human potential of creativity, compassion and understanding which had been blocked and shut out. Moksha is more than liberation from life-rebirth cycle of suffering (samsara); Vedantic school separates this into two: jivanmukti (liberation in this life) and videhamukti (liberation after death).<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Concept_of_God">Concept of God</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a> and <a href="/wiki/God_in_Hinduism" title="God in Hinduism">God in Hinduism</a></div>
<p>Hinduism is a diverse system of thought with beliefs spanning <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polytheism" title="Polytheism">polytheism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Panentheism" title="Panentheism">panentheism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_views_on_Pantheism" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu views on Pantheism">pantheism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pandeism" title="Pandeism">pandeism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monism" title="Monism">monism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Atheism_in_Hinduism" title="Atheism in Hinduism">atheism</a> among others;<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EBpolytheism_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EBpolytheism-201">&#91;web 3&#93;</a></sup> and its concept of God is complex and depends upon each individual and the tradition and philosophy followed. It is sometimes referred to as <a href="/wiki/Henotheistic" class="mw-redirect" title="Henotheistic">henotheistic</a> (i.e., involving devotion to a single god while accepting the existence of others), but any such term is an overgeneralization.<sup id="cite_ref-heno_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-heno-202">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="rquote pullquote floatleft" role="presentation" style="border-collapse:collapse; border-style:none; float:left; margin:0.5em 0.75em; width:33%;">

<tbody><tr style="text-align:left; vertical-align:top;">
<td style="color:#b2b7f2; font-size:3.3em; font-family:&#39;Times New Roman&#39;,serif; font-weight:bold; padding:4px 2px 2px; width:0.5em; line-height: 1em;">“
</td>
<td style="padding:0 10px;">Who really knows? <br />Who will here proclaim it? <br />Whence was it produced? Whence is this creation? <br />The gods came afterwards, with the creation of this universe. <br />Who then knows whence it has arisen?
</td>
<td style="color:#b2b7f2; font-size:3.3em; font-family:&#39;Times New Roman&#39;,serif; font-weight:bold; padding:4px 2px 2px; text-align:right; vertical-align:bottom; width:0.5em; line-height: 1em;">”
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td class="rquotecite" colspan="3" style="padding-top:10px; font-size:smaller; line-height:normal; text-align:right;"><cite>—&#160;<a href="/wiki/Nasadiya_Sukta" title="Nasadiya Sukta">Nasadiya Sukta</a>, concerns the <a href="/wiki/Origin_of_the_universe" class="mw-redirect" title="Origin of the universe">origin of the universe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rig_Veda" class="mw-redirect" title="Rig Veda">Rig Veda</a>, <i>10:129-6</i> <sup id="cite_ref-Kramer1986_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kramer1986-203">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Christian2011_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christian2011-204">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Singh2008_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Singh2008-205">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup></cite>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Nasadiya_Sukta" title="Nasadiya Sukta">Nasadiya Sukta</a></i> (<i>Creation Hymn</i>) of the <i><a href="/wiki/Rig_Veda" class="mw-redirect" title="Rig Veda">Rig Veda</a></i> is one of the earliest texts<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996226_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996226-206">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> which "demonstrates a sense of metaphysical speculation" about what created the universe, the concept of god(s) and The One, and whether even The One knows how the universe came into being.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3translations_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3translations-208">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> The <i>Rig Veda</i> praises various deities, none superior nor inferior, in a henotheistic manner.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> The hymns repeatedly refer to One Truth and Reality. The "One Truth" of Vedic literature, in modern era scholarship, has been interpreted as monotheism, monism, as well as a deified Hidden Principles behind the great happenings and processes of nature.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Durga</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:124px;max-width:124px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:174px;overflow:hidden"><a src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg/122px-A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg" decoding="async" width="122" height="175" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg/183px-A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg/244px-A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2112" data-file-height="3025" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Lakshmi</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:114px;max-width:114px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:174px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:God_Vishnu.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Vishnu" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/God_Vishnu.jpg/112px-God_Vishnu.jpg" decoding="async" width="112" height="174" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/God_Vishnu.jpg/168px-God_Vishnu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/God_Vishnu.jpg/224px-God_Vishnu.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2043" data-file-height="3167" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Vishnu</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Hindus believe that all living creatures have a soul. This soul – the spirit or true "self" of every person, is called the <i><a href="/wiki/Atman_(Hinduism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Atman (Hinduism)">ātman</a></i>. The soul is believed to be eternal.<sup id="cite_ref-monierwilliams2037_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-monierwilliams2037-211">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> According to the monistic/pantheistic (<a href="/wiki/Nondualism" title="Nondualism">non-dualist</a>) theologies of Hinduism (such as <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a> school), this Atman is indistinct from <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>, the supreme spirit.<sup id="cite_ref-bhaskaranandaessential_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bhaskaranandaessential-212">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> The goal of life, according to the Advaita school, is to realise that one's soul is identical to supreme soul, that the supreme soul is present in everything and everyone, all life is interconnected and there is oneness in all life.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dualism_(Indian_philosophy)" title="Dualism (Indian philosophy)">Dualistic</a> schools (see <a href="/wiki/Dvaita" class="mw-redirect" title="Dvaita">Dvaita</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">Bhakti</a>) understand Brahman as a Supreme Being separate from individual souls.<sup id="cite_ref-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347-216">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup> They worship the Supreme Being variously as <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brahma" title="Brahma">Brahma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a>, depending upon the sect.
