God is called <i><a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavan" title="Bhagavan">Bhagavan</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Parameshwara_(God)" title="Parameshwara (God)">Parameshwara</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)" title="Deva (Hinduism)">Deva</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi">Devi</a></i>, and these terms have different meanings in different schools of Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MW_Sanskrit_dict._219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MW_Sanskrit_dict.-219">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Hindu texts accept a polytheistic framework, but this is generally conceptualized as the divine essence or luminosity that gives vitality and animation to the inanimate natural substances.<sup id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-220">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> There is a divine in everything, human beings, animals, trees and rivers. It is observable in offerings to rivers, trees, tools of one's work, animals and birds, rising sun, friends and guests, teachers and parents.<sup id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-220">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup> It is the divine in these that makes each sacred and worthy of reverence. This seeing divinity in everything, state Buttimer and Wallin, makes the Vedic foundations of Hinduism quite distinct from <a href="/wiki/Animism" title="Animism">Animism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_220-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-220">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> The animistic premise sees multiplicity, power differences and competition between man and man, man and animal, as well as <a href="/wiki/Man_and_nature" class="mw-redirect" title="Man and nature">man and nature</a>. The Vedic view does not see this competition, rather sees a unifying divinity that connects everyone and everything.<sup id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_220-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-220">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Hindu scriptures refer to celestial entities called <i><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)" title="Deva (Hinduism)">Devas</a></i> (or <i><a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi"><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">devī</i></a></i> in feminine form; <i><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">devatā</i></i> used synonymously for <i>Deva</i> in Hindi), which may be translated into English as <i>gods</i> or <i>heavenly beings</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;note 17&#93;</a></sup> The devas are an integral part of Hindu culture and are depicted in art, architecture and through <a href="/wiki/Icon" title="Icon">icons</a>, and stories about them are related in the scriptures, particularly in <a href="/wiki/Indian_epic_poetry" title="Indian epic poetry">Indian epic poetry</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Puranas</a>. They are, however, often distinguished from <a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a>, a personal god, with many Hindus worshipping Ishvara in one of its particular manifestations as their <i><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><a href="/wiki/I%E1%B9%A3%E1%B9%ADa_devat%C4%81" class="mw-redirect" title="Iṣṭa devatā">iṣṭa devatā</a></i></i>, or chosen ideal.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner20059,_15,_49,_54,_86_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner20059,_15,_49,_54,_86-226">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup> The choice is a matter of individual preference,<sup id="cite_ref-harman1_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harman1-228">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup> and of regional and family traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-harman1_228-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-harman1-228">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;note 18&#93;</a></sup> The multitude of Devas are considered as manifestations of Brahman.<sup id="cite_ref-avatars_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-avatars-231">&#91;note 19&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The word <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar" title="Avatar">avatar</a></i> does not appear in the Vedic literature,<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> but appears in verb forms in post-Vedic literature, and as a noun particularly in the <a href="/wiki/Purana" class="mw-redirect" title="Purana">Puranic</a> literature after the 6th century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> Theologically, the reincarnation idea is most often associated with the <i>avatars</i> of Hindu god <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a>, though the idea has been applied to other deities.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> Varying lists of avatars of Vishnu appear in Hindu scriptures, including the ten <a href="/wiki/Dashavatara" title="Dashavatara">Dashavatara</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Garuda_Purana" title="Garuda Purana">Garuda Purana</a></i> and the twenty-two avatars in the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavata_Purana" title="Bhagavata Purana">Bhagavata Purana</a></i>, though the latter adds that the incarnations of Vishnu are innumerable.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> The avatars of Vishnu are important in <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> theology. In the goddess-based <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> tradition of Hinduism, avatars of the <a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi">Devi</a> are found and all goddesses are considered to be different aspects of the same metaphysical Brahman<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> and Shakti (energy).<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> While avatars of other deities such as <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> are also mentioned in medieval Hindu texts, this is minor and occasional.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Both theistic and atheistic ideas, for epistemological and metaphysical reasons, are profuse in different schools of Hinduism. The early <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyaya</a> school of Hinduism, for example, was non-theist/atheist,<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> but later Nyaya school scholars argued that God exists and offered proofs using its theory of logic.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ccbs.ntu.edu.tw_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ccbs.ntu.edu.tw-242">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup> Other schools disagreed with Nyaya scholars. <a href="/wiki/Samkhya" title="Samkhya">Samkhya</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mimamsa" class="mw-redirect" title="Mimamsa">Mimamsa</a><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Carvaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Carvaka">Carvaka</a> schools of Hinduism, were non-theist/atheist, arguing that "God was an unnecessary metaphysical assumption".<sup id="cite_ref-samkhyaatheism_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-samkhyaatheism-245">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;web 4&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Vaisheshika" title="Vaisheshika">Vaisheshika</a> school started as another non-theistic tradition relying on naturalism and that all matter is eternal, but it later introduced the concept of a non-creator God.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-klausk_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-klausk-249">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Raja_yoga" class="mw-redirect" title="Raja yoga">Yoga</a> school of Hinduism accepted the concept of a "personal god" and left it to the Hindu to define his or her god.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> Advaita Vedanta taught a monistic, abstract Self and Oneness in everything, with no room for gods or deity, a perspective that Mohanty calls, "spiritual, not religious".<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> Bhakti sub-schools of Vedanta taught a creator God that is distinct from each human being.<sup id="cite_ref-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347-216">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Graham_Schweig" title="Graham Schweig">Graham Schweig</a>, Hinduism has the strongest presence of the divine feminine in world religion from ancient times to the present.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryant2007441_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryant2007441-252">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> The goddess is viewed as the heart of the most esoteric Saiva traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Authority">Authority</span></h3>
<p>Authority and eternal truths play an important role in Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-frazier1415_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-254">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> Religious traditions and truths are believed to be contained in its sacred texts, which are accessed and taught by sages, <a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">gurus</a>, saints or <a href="/wiki/Avatar" title="Avatar">avatars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-frazier1415_254-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-254">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> But there is also a strong tradition of the questioning of authority, internal debate and challenging of religious texts in Hinduism. The Hindus believe that this deepens the understanding of the eternal truths and further develops the tradition. Authority "was mediated through [...] an intellectual culture that tended to develop ideas collaboratively, and according to the shared logic of natural reason."<sup id="cite_ref-frazier1415_254-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-254">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> Narratives in the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> present characters questioning persons of authority.<sup id="cite_ref-frazier1415_254-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-254">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kena_Upanishad" title="Kena Upanishad">Kena Upanishad</a> repeatedly asks <i>kena</i>, 'by what' power something is the case.<sup id="cite_ref-frazier1415_254-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-254">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Katha_Upanishad" title="Katha Upanishad">Katha Upanishad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a> present narratives where the student criticizes the teacher's inferior answers.<sup id="cite_ref-frazier1415_254-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-254">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Shiva_Purana" title="Shiva Purana">Shiva Purana</a>, Shiva questions Vishnu and Brahma.<sup id="cite_ref-frazier1415_254-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-254">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> Doubt plays a repeated role in the <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-frazier1415_254-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-254">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jayadeva" title="Jayadeva">Jayadeva's</a> <a href="/wiki/Gita_Govinda" title="Gita Govinda">Gita Govinda</a> presents criticism via the character of <a href="/wiki/Radha" title="Radha">Radha</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-frazier1415_254-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-254">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Main_traditions">Main traditions</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">Hindu denominations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg/220px-Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="296" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg/330px-Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg/440px-Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg 2x" data-file-width="594" data-file-height="800" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Ganesha-centric <a href="/wiki/Panchayatana_puja" title="Panchayatana puja">Panchayatana</a> ("five deities", from the Smarta tradition): <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> (centre) with <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> (top left), <a href="/wiki/Parvati" title="Parvati">Parvati</a> (top right), <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a> (bottom left) and Surya (bottom right). All these deities also have separate sects dedicated to them.</div></div></div>
<p>Hinduism has no central doctrinal authority and many practising Hindus do not claim to belong to any particular denomination or tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> Four major denominations are, however, used in scholarly studies: <i>Vaishnavism</i>, <i>Shaivism</i>, <i>Shaktism</i> and <i>Smartism</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-lancenelson_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-256">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_134,_155–161,_167–168_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_134,_155–161,_167–168-257">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> These denominations differ primarily in the central deity worshipped, the traditions and the <a href="/wiki/Soteriology" title="Soteriology">soteriological</a> outlook.<sup id="cite_ref-sskumar_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-258">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> The denominations of Hinduism, states Lipner, are unlike those found in major religions of the world, because Hindu denominations are fuzzy with individuals practicing more than one, and he suggests the term "Hindu polycentrism".<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> is the devotional religious tradition that worships <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> and his avatars, particularly <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Krishna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rama" title="Rama">Rama</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> The adherents of this sect are generally non-ascetic, monastic, oriented towards community events and devotionalism practices inspired by "intimate loving, joyous, playful" <i>Krishna</i> and other Vishnu avatars.<sup id="cite_ref-sskumar_258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-258">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> These practices sometimes include community dancing, singing of <a href="/wiki/Kirtan" title="Kirtan">Kirtans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">Bhajans</a>, with sound and music believed by some to have meditative and spiritual powers.<sup id="cite_ref-edwinb_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edwinb-262">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup> Temple worship and festivals are typically elaborate in Vaishnavism.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> The Bhagavad Gita and the Ramayana, along with Vishnu-oriented Puranas provide its theistic foundations.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> Philosophically, their beliefs are rooted in the dualism sub-schools of Vedantic Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> is the tradition that focuses on <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a>. Shaivas are more attracted to ascetic individualism, and it has several sub-schools.<sup id="cite_ref-sskumar_258-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-258">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> Their practices include Bhakti-style devotionalism, yet their beliefs lean towards nondual, monistic schools of Hinduism such as Advaita and <a href="/wiki/Raja_yoga" class="mw-redirect" title="Raja yoga">Yoga</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-lancenelson_256-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-256">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-edwinb_262-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edwinb-262">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup> Some Shaivas worship in temples, while others emphasize yoga, striving to be one with Shiva within.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> Avatars are uncommon, and some Shaivas visualize god as half male, half female, as a fusion of the male and female principles (<a href="/wiki/Ardhanarishvara" title="Ardhanarishvara">Ardhanarishvara</a>). Shaivism is related to Shaktism, wherein Shakti is seen as spouse of Shiva.<sup id="cite_ref-lancenelson_256-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-256">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup> Community celebrations include festivals, and participation, with Vaishnavas, in pilgrimages such as the <a href="/wiki/Kumbh_Mela" title="Kumbh Mela">Kumbh Mela</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> Shaivism has been more commonly practiced in the Himalayan north from Kashmir to Nepal, and in south India.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> focuses on goddess worship of <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a> or Devi as cosmic mother,<sup id="cite_ref-sskumar_258-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-258">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> and it is particularly common in northeastern and eastern states of India such as <a href="/wiki/Assam" title="Assam">Assam</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">Bengal</a>. Devi is depicted as in gentler forms like <a href="/wiki/Parvati" title="Parvati">Parvati</a>, the consort of Shiva; or, as fierce warrior goddesses like <a href="/wiki/Kali" title="Kali">Kali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Durga" title="Durga">Durga</a>. Followers of Shaktism recognize <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a> as the power that underlies the male principle. Shaktism is also associated with <a href="/wiki/Tantra" title="Tantra">Tantra</a> practices.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> Community celebrations include festivals, some of which include processions and idol immersion into sea or other water bodies.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Smartism" class="mw-redirect" title="Smartism">Smartism</a> centers its worship simultaneously on all the major Hindu deities: Shiva, Vishnu, Shakti, <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Surya" title="Surya">Surya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kartikeya" title="Kartikeya">Skanda</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113-272">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup> The Smarta tradition developed during the (early) Classical Period of Hinduism around the beginning of the Common Era, when Hinduism emerged from the interaction between Brahmanism and local traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996-274">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> The Smarta tradition is aligned with <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>, and regards <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a> as its founder or reformer, who considered worship of God-with-attributes (<a href="/wiki/Saguna_Brahman" class="mw-redirect" title="Saguna Brahman">Saguna Brahman</a>) as a journey towards ultimately realizing God-without-attributes (nirguna Brahman, Atman, Self-knowledge).<sup id="cite_ref-williamw_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-williamw-275">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> The term <i>Smartism</i> is derived from Smriti texts of Hinduism, meaning those who remember the traditions in the texts.<sup id="cite_ref-lancenelson_256-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-256">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-williamsonp89_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-williamsonp89-277">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> This Hindu sect practices a philosophical <a href="/wiki/Jnana_yoga" title="Jnana yoga">Jnana yoga</a>, scriptural studies, reflection, meditative path seeking an understanding of Self's oneness with God.<sup id="cite_ref-lancenelson_256-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-256">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Scriptures">Scriptures</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rigveda_MS2097.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/220px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="213" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/330px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/440px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1161" data-file-height="1125" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Rigveda_MS2097.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i> is the first and most important Veda<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> and is one of the oldest <a href="/wiki/Religious_texts" class="mw-redirect" title="Religious texts">religious texts</a>. This Rigveda <a href="/wiki/Manuscript" title="Manuscript">manuscript</a> is in <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a>.</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Shruti" class="mw-redirect" title="Shruti">Shruti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smriti" title="Smriti">Smriti</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Hindu_scriptures" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Hindu scriptures">List of Hindu scriptures</a></div>
<p>The ancient scriptures of Hinduism are in Sanskrit. These texts are classified into two: Shruti and Smriti. Hindu scriptures were composed, memorized and transmitted verbally, across generations, for many centuries before they were written down.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> Over many centuries, sages refined the teachings and expanded the Shruti and Smriti, as well as developed Shastras with epistemological and metaphysical theories of six classical schools of Hinduism.
</p><p><i>Shruti</i> (lit. that which is heard)<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERinehart200468_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERinehart200468-282">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> primarily refers to the <i>Vedas</i>, which form the earliest record of the Hindu scriptures, and are regarded as eternal truths revealed to the ancient sages (<i><a href="/wiki/Rishi" title="Rishi">rishis</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood20084_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood20084-283">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> There are four <i>Vedas</i> – <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Samaveda" title="Samaveda">Samaveda</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Yajurveda" title="Yajurveda">Yajurveda</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Atharvaveda" title="Atharvaveda">Atharvaveda</a></i>. Each Veda has been subclassified into four major text types – the <a href="/wiki/Samhita" title="Samhita">Samhitas</a> (mantras and benedictions), the <a href="/wiki/Aranyakas" class="mw-redirect" title="Aranyakas">Aranyakas</a> (text on rituals, ceremonies, sacrifices and symbolic-sacrifices), the <a href="/wiki/Brahmanas" class="mw-redirect" title="Brahmanas">Brahmanas</a> (commentaries on rituals, ceremonies and sacrifices), and the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> (text discussing meditation, philosophy and spiritual knowledge).<sup id="cite_ref-gflood_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gflood-284">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> The first two parts of the Vedas were subsequently called the <i><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">Karmakāṇḍa</i></i> (ritualistic portion), while the last two form the <i><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">Jñānakāṇḍa</i></i> (knowledge portion, discussing spiritual insight and philosophical teachings).<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Upanishads are the foundation of Hindu philosophical thought, and have profoundly influenced diverse traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-wendydoniger_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wendydoniger-291">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> Of the Shrutis (Vedic corpus), they alone are widely influential among Hindus, considered scriptures par excellence of Hinduism, and their central ideas have continued to influence its thoughts and traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-wendydoniger_291-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wendydoniger-291">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sarvepalli_Radhakrishnan" title="Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan">Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan</a> states that the Upanishads have played a dominating role ever since their appearance.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup> There are 108 <a href="/wiki/Muktik%C4%81" title="Muktikā">Muktikā</a> Upanishads in Hinduism, of which between 10 and 13 are variously counted by scholars as <a href="/wiki/Mukhya_Upanishads" title="Mukhya Upanishads">Principal Upanishads</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The most notable of the Smritis ("remembered") are the Hindu epics and the <i>Puranas</i>. The epics consist of the <i><a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></i>. The <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a></i> is an integral part of the <i>Mahabharata</i> and one of the most popular sacred texts of Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> It is sometimes called <i>Gitopanishad</i>, then placed in the Shruti ("heard") category, being Upanishadic in content.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup> The <i>Puranas</i>, which started to be composed from c. 300 CE onward,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999655_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999655-299">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> contain extensive mythologies, and are central in the distribution of common themes of Hinduism through vivid narratives. The <i><a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras" class="mw-redirect" title="Yoga Sutras">Yoga Sutras</a></i> is a classical text for the Hindu Yoga tradition, which gained a renewed popularity in the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the 19th-century Indian modernists have re-asserted the 'Aryan origins' of Hinduism, "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233_99-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233-99">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup> and elevating the Vedic elements. Hindu modernists like Vivekananda see the Vedas as the laws of the spiritual world, which would still exist even if they were not revealed to the sages.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> In Tantric tradition, the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Hinduism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Āgama (Hinduism)">Agamas</a></i> refer to authoritative scriptures or the teachings of Shiva to Shakti,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200613_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200613-303">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> while <i>Nigamas</i> refers to the Vedas and the teachings of Shakti to Shiva.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200613_303-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200613-303">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> In Agamic schools of Hinduism, the Vedic literature and the Agamas are equally authoritative.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Practices">Practices</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rituals">Rituals</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja (Hinduism)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aarti" title="Aarti">Aarti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abhisheka" title="Abhisheka">Abhisheka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">Japa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Havan" class="mw-redirect" title="Havan">Havan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">Yajna</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_wedding" title="Hindu wedding">Hindu wedding</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:(A)_Hindu_wedding,_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg/200px-%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg/300px-%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg/400px-%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2304" data-file-height="1728" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:(A)_Hindu_wedding,_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A wedding is the most extensive personal ritual an adult Hindu undertakes in his or her life. A typical <a href="/wiki/Hindu_wedding" title="Hindu wedding">Hindu wedding</a> is solemnized before Vedic <a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">fire</a> ritual (shown).<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Most Hindus observe religious rituals at home.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup> The rituals vary greatly among regions, villages, and individuals. They are not mandatory in Hinduism. The nature and place of rituals is an individual's choice. Some devout Hindus perform daily rituals such as worshiping at dawn after bathing (usually at a family shrine, and typically includes lighting a lamp and offering foodstuffs before the images of deities), recitation from religious scripts, singing <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">devotional hymns</a>, yoga, <a href="/wiki/Meditation" title="Meditation">meditation</a>, chanting mantras and others.<sup id="cite_ref-locceremonies_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locceremonies-308">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Vedic rituals of fire-oblation (<i><a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">yajna</a></i>) and chanting of Vedic hymns are observed on special occasions, such as a Hindu wedding.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> Other major life-stage events, such as rituals after death, include the <i>yajña</i> and chanting of Vedic <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">mantras</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;web 5&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Life-cycle_rites_of_passage">Life-cycle rites of passage</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83sk%C4%81ra" class="mw-redirect" title="Saṃskāra">Saṃskāra</a></div>
<p>Major life stage milestones are celebrated as <i>sanskara</i> (<i>saṃskāra</i>, <a href="/wiki/Rites_of_passage" class="mw-redirect" title="Rites of passage">rites of passage</a>) in Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-pandey_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pandey-311">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-knipe_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-knipe-312">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> The rites of passage are not mandatory, and vary in details by gender, community and regionally.<sup id="cite_ref-pvkanesamsk_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pvkanesamsk-313">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> Gautama <a href="/wiki/Dharmasutra" class="mw-redirect" title="Dharmasutra">Dharmasutras</a> composed in about the middle of 1st millennium BCE lists 48 sanskaras,<sup id="cite_ref-patrick_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-patrick-314">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Kalpa_(Vedanga)" title="Kalpa (Vedanga)">Gryhasutra</a> and other texts composed centuries later list between 12 and 16 sanskaras.<sup id="cite_ref-pandey_311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pandey-311">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-carlolson_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carlolson-315">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> The list of sanskaras in Hinduism include both external rituals such as those marking a baby's birth and a baby's name giving ceremony, as well as inner rites of resolutions and ethics such as <a href="/wiki/Compassion#Hinduism" title="Compassion">compassion</a> towards all living beings and positive attitude.<sup id="cite_ref-patrick_314-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-patrick-314">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The major traditional rites of passage in Hinduism include<sup id="cite_ref-pvkanesamsk_313-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pvkanesamsk-313">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Garbhadhana" title="Garbhadhana">Garbhadhana</a> (pregnancy), <a href="/wiki/Pumsavana" title="Pumsavana">Pumsavana</a> (rite before the fetus begins moving and kicking in womb), <a href="/wiki/Simantonnayana" title="Simantonnayana">Simantonnayana</a> (parting of pregnant woman's hair, baby shower), <i>Jatakarman</i> (rite celebrating the new born baby), <i>Namakarana</i> (naming the child), <i>Nishkramana</i> (baby's first outing from home into the world), <i>Annaprashana</i> (baby's first feeding of solid food), <i>Chudakarana</i> (baby's first haircut, tonsure), <i>Karnavedha</i> (ear piercing), <i>Vidyarambha</i> (baby's start with knowledge), <a href="/wiki/Upanayana" title="Upanayana">Upanayana</a> (entry into a school rite),<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup> <i>Keshanta</i> and <i>Ritusuddhi</i> (first shave for boys, menarche for girls), <a href="/wiki/Samavartana" class="mw-redirect" title="Samavartana">Samavartana</a> (graduation ceremony), Vivaha (wedding), <i>Vratas</i> (fasting, spiritual studies) and <a href="/wiki/Antyeshti" class="mw-redirect" title="Antyeshti">Antyeshti</a> (cremation for an adult, burial for a child).<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup> In contemporary times, there is regional variation among Hindus as to which of these <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83sk%C4%81ra" class="mw-redirect" title="Saṃskāra">sanskaras</a> are observed; in some cases, additional regional rites of passage such as <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81ddha" title="Śrāddha">Śrāddha</a></i> (ritual of feeding people after cremation) are practiced.<sup id="cite_ref-pvkanesamsk_313-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pvkanesamsk-313">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-loclifecycle_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-loclifecycle-319">&#91;web 6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Bhakti_.28worship.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Bhakti_(worship)">Bhakti (worship)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">Bhakti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja (Hinduism)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">Japa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">Mantra</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">Bhajan</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:320px;max-width:320px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Vishu-kani_1.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Vishu-kani_1.JPG/200px-Vishu-kani_1.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Vishu-kani_1.JPG/300px-Vishu-kani_1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Vishu-kani_1.JPG/400px-Vishu-kani_1.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:114px;max-width:114px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg/112px-Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg" decoding="async" width="112" height="149" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg/168px-Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg/224px-Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="800" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:left;background-color:transparent">A home shrine with offerings at a regional <a href="/wiki/Vishu" title="Vishu">Vishu</a> festival (left); a priest in a temple (right).</div></div></div></div>
<p><i>Bhakti</i> refers to devotion, participation in and the love of a personal god or a representational god by a devotee.<sup id="cite_ref-encyclopediabrit_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encyclopediabrit-320">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-karen_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-karen-321">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> <i>Bhakti marga</i> is considered in Hinduism as one of many possible paths of spirituality and alternative means to moksha.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup> The other paths, left to the choice of a Hindu, are <i>Jnana marga</i> (path of knowledge), <i>Karma marga</i> (path of works), <i>Rāja marga</i> (path of contemplation and meditation).<sup id="cite_ref-johnmartin_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-johnmartin-323">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bhakti is practiced in a number of ways, ranging from reciting <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">mantras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">japas</a> (incantations), to individual private prayers within one's home shrine,<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> or in a temple or near a river bank, sometimes in the presence of an idol or image of a deity.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199741-50_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199741-50-327">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temples</a> and domestic altars, states Lynn Foulston, are important elements of worship in contemporary theistic Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-Foulston2012p20_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foulston2012p20-328">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> While many visit a temple on a special occasion, most offer a brief prayer on an everyday basis at the domestic altar.<sup id="cite_ref-Foulston2012p20_328-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foulston2012p20-328">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> This bhakti is expressed in a domestic shrine which typically is a dedicated part of the home and includes the images of deities or the gurus the Hindu chooses.<sup id="cite_ref-Foulston2012p20_328-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foulston2012p20-328">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> Among Vaishnavism sub-traditions such as Swaminarayan, the home shrines can be elaborate with either a room dedicated to it or a dedicated part of the kitchen. The devotee uses this space for daily prayers or meditation, either before breakfast or after day's work.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bhakti is sometimes private inside household shrines and sometimes practiced as a community. It may include <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aarti" title="Aarti">Aarti</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup> musical <a href="/wiki/Kirtan" title="Kirtan">Kirtan</a> or singing <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">Bhajan</a>, where devotional verses and hymns are read or poems are sung by a group of devotees.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup> While the choice of the deity is at the discretion of the Hindu, the most observed traditions of Hindu devotionalism include <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> (Vishnu), <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> (Shiva) and <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> (Shakti).<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> A Hindu may worship multiple deities, all as henotheistic manifestations of the same ultimate reality, cosmic spirit and absolute spiritual concept called <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a> in Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-avatars_231-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-avatars-231">&#91;note 19&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bhakti marga, states Pechelis, is more than ritual devotionalism, it includes practices and spiritual activities aimed at refining one's state of mind, knowing god, participating in god, and internalizing god.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Gale_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gale-338">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup> While Bhakti practices are popular and easily observable aspect of Hinduism, not all Hindus practice Bhakti, or believe in god-with-attributes (<i>saguna Brahman</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup> Concurrent Hindu practices include a belief in god-without-attributes, and god within oneself.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals">Festivals</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_festivals" class="mw-redirect" title="Hindu festivals">Hindu festivals</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Deepawali-festival.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Deepawali-festival.jpg/300px-Deepawali-festival.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="216" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5e/Deepawali-festival.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="416" data-file-height="300" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Deepawali-festival.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The festival of lights, <a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a>, is celebrated by Hindus all over the world.</div></div></div>
<p>Hindu festivals (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: <i>Utsava</i>; literally: "to lift higher") are ceremonies that weave individual and social life to dharma.<sup id="cite_ref-sandrarobinson_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sandrarobinson-343">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-yustf_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yustf-344">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup> Hinduism has many festivals throughout the year, where the dates are set by the lunisolar <a href="/wiki/Hindu_calendar" title="Hindu calendar">Hindu calendar</a>, many coinciding with either the full moon (<i>Holi</i>) or the new moon (<i>Diwali</i>), often with seasonal changes.<sup id="cite_ref-denisecushf_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-denisecushf-345">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup> Some festivals are found only regionally and they celebrate local traditions, while a few such as <i>Holi</i> and <i>Diwali</i> are pan-Hindu.<sup id="cite_ref-denisecushf_345-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-denisecushf-345">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The festivals typically celebrate events from Hinduism, connoting spiritual themes and celebrating aspects of human relationships such as the Sister-Brother bond over the <i>Raksha Bandhan</i> (or <a href="/wiki/Bhau-beej" class="mw-redirect" title="Bhau-beej">Bhai Dooj</a>) festival.<sup id="cite_ref-yustf_344-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yustf-344">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup> The same festival sometimes marks different stories depending on the Hindu denomination, and the celebrations incorporate regional themes, traditional agriculture, local arts, family get togethers, <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja</a> rituals and feasts.<sup id="cite_ref-sandrarobinson_343-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sandrarobinson-343">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Some major regional or pan-Hindu festivals include:
</p>
<div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 18em; -webkit-column-width: 18em; column-width: 18em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Makar_Sankranti" title="Makar Sankranti">Makar Sankranti</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pongal" class="mw-redirect" title="Pongal">Pongal</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Thaipusam" title="Thaipusam">Thaipusam</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vasant_Panchami" title="Vasant Panchami">Vasant Panchami</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Maha_Shivaratri" title="Maha Shivaratri">Maha Shivaratri</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shigmo" title="Shigmo">Shigmo</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Holi" title="Holi">Holi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gudi_Padwa" title="Gudi Padwa">Gudi Padwa</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ugadi" title="Ugadi">Ugadi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bihu" title="Bihu">Bihu</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vishu" title="Vishu">Vishu</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ram_Navami" class="mw-redirect" title="Ram Navami">Ram Navami</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Guru_Purnima" title="Guru Purnima">Guru Purnima</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Raksha_Bandhan" title="Raksha Bandhan">Raksha Bandhan</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Krishna_Janmastami" class="mw-redirect" title="Krishna Janmastami">Krishna Janmastami</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gowri_Habba" title="Gowri Habba">Gowri Habba</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ganesh_Chaturthi" title="Ganesh Chaturthi">Ganesh Chaturthi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Onam" title="Onam">Onam</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Navaratri" title="Navaratri">Navaratri</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dussera" class="mw-redirect" title="Dussera">Dussera</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Durga_Puja" title="Durga Puja">Durga Puja</a> or <a href="/wiki/Durga_Ashtami" title="Durga Ashtami">Durga Ashtami</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chhath" title="Chhath">Chhath</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bonalu" title="Bonalu">Bonalu</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Rath_Yatra" class="mw-redirect" title="Rath Yatra">Rath Yatra</a></li></ul>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pilgrimage">Pilgrimage</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Tirtha_(Hinduism)" title="Tirtha (Hinduism)">Tirtha (Hinduism)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_pilgrimage_sites_in_India" title="Hindu pilgrimage sites in India">Tirtha locations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yatra" title="Yatra">Yatra</a></div>
<p>Many adherents undertake <a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage" title="Pilgrimage">pilgrimages</a>, which have historically been an important part of Hinduism and remain so today.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller2004204–05_349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller2004204–05-349">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup> Pilgrimage sites are called <i><a href="/wiki/Tirtha_(Hinduism)" title="Tirtha (Hinduism)">Tirtha</a></i>, <i>Kshetra</i>, <i>Gopitha</i> or <i>Mahalaya</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJames_G._Lochtefeld2002698–699_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJames_G._Lochtefeld2002698–699-350">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnut_A._Jacobsen20134,_22,_27,_140–148,_157–158_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnut_A._Jacobsen20134,_22,_27,_140–148,_157–158-351">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup> The process or journey associated with <i>Tirtha</i> is called <i>Tirtha-yatra</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19832_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19832-352">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup> According to the Hindu text <i><a href="/wiki/Skanda_Purana" title="Skanda Purana">Skanda Purana</a></i>, Tirtha are of three kinds: Jangam Tirtha is to a place movable of a <a href="/wiki/Sadhu" title="Sadhu">sadhu</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Rishi" title="Rishi">rishi</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">guru</a>; Sthawar Tirtha is to a place immovable, like Benaras, Haridwar, Mount Kailash, holy rivers; while Manas Tirtha is to a place of mind of truth, charity, patience, compassion, soft speech, soul.<sup id="cite_ref-sharmasinha_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sharmasinha-353">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup> <i>Tīrtha-yatra</i> is, states Knut A. Jacobsen, anything that has a salvific value to a Hindu, and includes pilgrimage sites such as mountains or forests or seashore or rivers or ponds, as well as virtues, actions, studies or state of mind.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnut_A._Jacobsen2013157–158_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnut_A._Jacobsen2013157–158-355">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAxel_MichaelsBarbara_Harshav_(Transl)2004288–289_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAxel_MichaelsBarbara_Harshav_(Transl)2004288–289-356">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Pilgrimage sites of Hinduism are mentioned in the epic Mahabharata and the <a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Puranas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953561_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953561-357">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20127–9_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20127–9-358">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> Most Puranas include large sections on <i>Tirtha Mahatmya</i> along with tourist guides,<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup> which describe sacred sites and places to visit.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953559-560_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953559-560-360">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup> In these texts, <a href="/wiki/Varanasi" title="Varanasi">Varanasi</a> (Benares, Kashi), <a href="/wiki/Rameshwaram" class="mw-redirect" title="Rameshwaram">Rameshwaram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kanchipuram" title="Kanchipuram">Kanchipuram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dwarka" title="Dwarka">Dwarka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puri" title="Puri">Puri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haridwar" title="Haridwar">Haridwar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sri_Rangam" class="mw-redirect" title="Sri Rangam">Sri Rangam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vrindavan" title="Vrindavan">Vrindavan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ayodhya" title="Ayodhya">Ayodhya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tirupati" title="Tirupati">Tirupati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mayapur" title="Mayapur">Mayapur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathdwara" title="Nathdwara">Nathdwara</a>, twelve <a href="/wiki/Jyotirlinga" title="Jyotirlinga">Jyotirlinga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shakti_Peetha" title="Shakti Peetha">Shakti Peetha</a> have been mentioned as particularly holy sites, along with geographies where major rivers meet (<i>sangam</i>) or join the sea.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953553–556,_560–561_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953553–556,_560–561-363">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20127–9_358-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20127–9-358">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kumbhamela" class="mw-redirect" title="Kumbhamela">Kumbhamela</a> is another major pilgrimage on the eve of the solar festival <a href="/wiki/Makar_Sankranti" title="Makar Sankranti">Makar Sankranti</a>. This pilgrimage rotates at a gap of three years among four sites:  <a href="/wiki/Prayag_Raj" class="mw-redirect" title="Prayag Raj">Prayag Raj</a> at the confluence of the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a>  and <a href="/wiki/Yamuna" title="Yamuna">Yamuna</a> rivers, <a href="/wiki/Haridwar" title="Haridwar">Haridwar</a> near source of the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ujjain" title="Ujjain">Ujjain</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Shipra" class="mw-redirect" title="Shipra">Shipra</a> river and <a href="/wiki/Nasik" class="mw-redirect" title="Nasik">Nasik</a> on the bank of the <a href="/wiki/Godavari" class="mw-redirect" title="Godavari">Godavari</a> river.<sup id="cite_ref-eck153_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eck153-364">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup> This is one of world's largest mass pilgrimage, with an estimated 40 to 100 million people attending the event.<sup id="cite_ref-eck153_364-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eck153-364">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlaus_K._Klostermaier2010553_note_55_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlaus_K._Klostermaier2010553_note_55-365">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup> At this event, they say a prayer to the sun and bathe in the river,<sup id="cite_ref-eck153_364-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eck153-364">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup> a tradition attributed to <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Some pilgrimages are part of a <i>Vrata</i> (vow), which a Hindu may make for a number of reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129–11_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129–11-368">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19836_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19836-369">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup> It may mark a special occasion, such as the birth of a baby, or as part of a <a href="/wiki/Sanskara_(rite_of_passage)" title="Sanskara (rite of passage)">rite of passage</a> such as a baby's first haircut, or after healing from a sickness.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-370">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> It may, states Eck, also be the result of prayers answered.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129_370-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-370">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup> An alternative reason for Tirtha, for some Hindus, is to respect wishes or in memory of a beloved person after his or her death.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129_370-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-370">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup> This may include dispersing their cremation ashes in a Tirtha region in a stream, river or sea to honor the wishes of the dead. The journey to a Tirtha, assert some Hindu texts, helps one overcome the sorrow of the loss.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129_370-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDiana_L._Eck20129-370">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">&#91;note 20&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Other reasons for a Tirtha in Hinduism is to rejuvenate or gain spiritual merit by traveling to famed temples or bathe in rivers such as the Ganges.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19833-5_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19833-5-375">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-holmbowker69_377-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-holmbowker69-377">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup> Tirtha has been one of the recommended means of addressing remorse and to perform penance, for unintentional errors and intentional sins, in the Hindu tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobert_Lingat197398-99_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobert_Lingat197398-99-378">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19834_379-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19834-379">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup> The proper procedure for a pilgrimage is widely discussed in Hindu texts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953573_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953573-380">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup> The most accepted view is that the greatest austerity comes from traveling on foot, or part of the journey is on foot, and that the use of a conveyance is only acceptable if the pilgrimage is otherwise impossible.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953576–577_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953576–577-381">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Person_and_society">Person and society</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Varnas">Varnas</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">Varna (Hinduism)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:12BCM11.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/12BCM11.jpg/220px-12BCM11.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/12BCM11.jpg/330px-12BCM11.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/12BCM11.jpg/440px-12BCM11.jpg 2x" data-file-width="945" data-file-height="628" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:12BCM11.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Brahmins at <a href="/wiki/Bhadrachalam_Temple" class="mw-redirect" title="Bhadrachalam Temple">Bhadrachalam Temple</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Telangana" title="Telangana">Telangana</a></div></div></div>
<p>Hindu society has been categorised into four classes, called <i>varnas</i>. They are the <i><a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmins</a></i>: Vedic teachers and priests; the <i><a href="/wiki/Kshatriya" title="Kshatriya">Kshatriyas</a></i>: warriors and kings; the <i><a href="/wiki/Vaishya" title="Vaishya">Vaishyas</a></i>: farmers and merchants; and the <i><a href="/wiki/Shudra" title="Shudra">Shudras</a></i>: servants and labourers.<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gītā</a></i> links the <i>varna</i> to an individual's duty (<i>svadharma</i>), inborn nature (<i>svabhāva</i>), and natural tendencies (<i><a href="/wiki/Gu%E1%B9%87a" title="Guṇa">guṇa</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass1995264_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass1995264-383">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Manusmriti" title="Manusmriti">Manusmṛiti</a></i> categorises the different castes.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">&#91;web 7&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Some mobility and flexibility within the varnas challenge allegations of social discrimination in the caste system, as has been pointed out by several sociologists,<sup id="cite_ref-Silverberg_Paper_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Silverberg_Paper-385">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup> although some other scholars disagree.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup> Scholars debate whether the so-called <i><a href="/wiki/Caste_system_in_India" title="Caste system in India">caste system</a></i> is part of Hinduism sanctioned by the scriptures or social custom.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">&#91;web 8&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">&#91;note 21&#93;</a></sup> And various contemporary scholars have argued that the caste system was constructed by the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British colonial regime</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">renunciant</a> man of knowledge is usually called <i>Varnatita</i> or "beyond all varnas" in Vedantic works. The bhiksu is advised to not bother about the caste of the family from which he begs his food. Scholars like Adi Sankara affirm that not only is Brahman beyond all varnas, the man who is identified with Him also transcends the distinctions and limitations of caste.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Yoga">Yoga</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Bangalore.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Shiva_Bangalore.jpg/200px-Shiva_Bangalore.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="198" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Shiva_Bangalore.jpg/300px-Shiva_Bangalore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Shiva_Bangalore.jpg/400px-Shiva_Bangalore.jpg 2x" data-file-width="832" data-file-height="822" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Bangalore.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A statue of <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> in yogic meditation</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a></div>
<p>In whatever way a Hindu defines the goal of life, there are several methods (yogas) that sages have taught for reaching that goal. Yoga is a Hindu discipline which trains the body, mind and consciousness for health, tranquility and spiritual insight. This is done through a system of postures and exercises to practise control of the body and mind.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup> Texts dedicated to Yoga include the <a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras" class="mw-redirect" title="Yoga Sutras">Yoga Sutras</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hatha_Yoga_Pradipika" title="Hatha Yoga Pradipika">Hatha Yoga Pradipika</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a> and, as their philosophical and historical basis, the Upanishads. Yoga is means, and the four major <i>marga</i> (paths) discussed in Hinduism are: <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_Yoga" class="mw-redirect" title="Bhakti Yoga">Bhakti Yoga</a> (the path of love and devotion), <a href="/wiki/Karma_Yoga" class="mw-redirect" title="Karma Yoga">Karma Yoga</a> (the path of right action), <a href="/wiki/R%C4%81ja_Yoga" class="mw-redirect" title="Rāja Yoga">Rāja Yoga</a> (the path of meditation), <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B1%C4%81na_Yoga" class="mw-redirect" title="Jñāna Yoga">Jñāna Yoga</a> (the path of wisdom)<sup id="cite_ref-bhaskaressentgeneral_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bhaskaressentgeneral-395">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup> An individual may prefer one or some yogas over others, according to his or her inclination and understanding. Practice of one yoga does not exclude others.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbolism">Symbolism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Three_basic_Hindu_symbols.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Three_basic_Hindu_symbols.jpg/220px-Three_basic_Hindu_symbols.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Three_basic_Hindu_symbols.jpg/330px-Three_basic_Hindu_symbols.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Three_basic_Hindu_symbols.jpg/440px-Three_basic_Hindu_symbols.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Three_basic_Hindu_symbols.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Basic Hindu symbols: Shatkona, Padma, and Swastika.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ganesha-aum.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ganesha-aum.jpg/200px-Ganesha-aum.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="215" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ganesha-aum.jpg/300px-Ganesha-aum.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ganesha-aum.jpg/400px-Ganesha-aum.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1684" data-file-height="1808" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ganesha-aum.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Hindu deity <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> is sometimes linked to the symbol <i><a href="/wiki/Om" title="Om">Om</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Hinduism has a developed system of symbolism and iconography to represent the sacred in art, architecture, literature and worship. These symbols gain their meaning from the scriptures or cultural traditions. The syllable <i><a href="/wiki/Om" title="Om">Om</a></i> (which represents the <i><a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Atman_(Hinduism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Atman (Hinduism)">Atman</a>) has grown to represent Hinduism itself, while other markings such as the <a href="/wiki/Swastika#Hinduism" title="Swastika">Swastika</a> sign represent auspiciousness,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger20001041_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger20001041-397">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Tilaka" title="Tilaka">Tilaka</a></i> (literally, seed) on forehead – considered to be the location of spiritual third eye,<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup> marks ceremonious welcome, blessing or one's participation in a ritual or rite of passage.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup> Elaborate <i>Tilaka</i> with lines may also identify a devotee of a particular denomination. Flowers, birds, animals, instruments, symmetric <a href="/wiki/Mandala" title="Mandala">mandala</a> drawings, objects, idols are all part of symbolic iconography in Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Ahimsa.2C_vegetarianism_and_other_food_customs"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Ahimsa,_vegetarianism_and_other_food_customs">Ahimsa, vegetarianism and other food customs</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">Ahimsa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diet_in_Hinduism" title="Diet in Hinduism">Diet in Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sattvic_diet" title="Sattvic diet">Sattvic diet</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mitahara" title="Mitahara">Mitahara</a></div>
<p>Hindus advocate the practice of <i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">ahiṃsā</i> (non-violence) and respect for all life because divinity is believed to permeate all beings, including plants and non-human animals.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup> The term <i><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">ahiṃsā</i></i> appears in the <a href="/wiki/Upanishad" class="mw-redirect" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Radhakrishnan_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Radhakrishnan-403">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup> the epic <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a><sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup> and <i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">ahiṃsā</i> is the first of the five <a href="/wiki/Yamas" title="Yamas">Yamas</a> (vows of self-restraint) in <a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras_of_Patanjali" title="Yoga Sutras of Patanjali">Patanjali's Yoga Sutras</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gosala_in_Guntur,_India.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg/200px-Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg/300px-Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg/400px-Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2272" data-file-height="1704" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gosala_in_Guntur,_India.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <i>goshala</i> or cow shelter at <a href="/wiki/Guntur" title="Guntur">Guntur</a></div></div></div>
<p>In accordance with <i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">ahiṃsā</i>, many Hindus embrace vegetarianism to respect higher forms of life. Estimates of strict <a href="/wiki/Lacto_vegetarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Lacto vegetarian">lacto vegetarians</a> in India (includes adherents of all religions) who never eat any meat, fish or eggs vary between 20% and 42%, while others are either less strict vegetarians or non-vegetarians.<sup id="cite_ref-veg_406-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-veg-406">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> Those who eat meat seek <a href="/wiki/Jhatka" title="Jhatka">Jhatka</a> (quick death) method of meat production, and dislike <a href="/wiki/Halal" title="Halal">Halal</a> (slow bled death) method, believing that quick death method reduces suffering to the animal.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> The food habits vary with region, with Bengali Hindus and Hindus living in Himalayan regions, or river delta regions, regularly eating meat and fish.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup> Some avoid meat on specific festivals or occasions.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup> Observant Hindus who do eat meat almost always abstain from beef. The <a href="/wiki/Cow" class="mw-redirect" title="Cow">cow</a> in Hindu society is traditionally identified as a caretaker and a maternal figure,<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> and Hindu society honours the cow as a symbol of unselfish giving.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There are many Hindu groups that have continued to abide by a strict <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Vegetarian">vegetarian</a> diet in modern times. Some adhere to a diet that is devoid of meat, eggs, and seafood.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup> Food affects body, mind and spirit in Hindu beliefs.<sup id="cite_ref-Vasudha_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vasudha-414">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rosen_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rosen-415">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup> Hindu texts such as Śāṇḍilya Upanishad<sup id="cite_ref-KN_Aiyar_1914_pages_173-176_416-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KN_Aiyar_1914_pages_173-176-416">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup> and Svātmārāma<sup id="cite_ref-svatmaram_417-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-svatmaram-417">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup> recommend <a href="/wiki/Mitahara" title="Mitahara">Mitahara</a> (eating in moderation) as one of the <a href="/wiki/Yamas" title="Yamas">Yamas</a> (virtuous self restraints). The Bhagavad Gita links body and mind to food one consumes in verses 17.8 through 17.10.<sup id="cite_ref-ckc_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ckc-419">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Some Hindus such as those belonging to the Shaktism tradition,<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup> and Hindus in regions such as Bali and Nepal<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200483,_Chapter_4_421-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200483,_Chapter_4-421">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup> practise <a href="/wiki/Animal_sacrifice_in_Hinduism" title="Animal sacrifice in Hinduism">animal sacrifice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200483,_Chapter_4_421-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200483,_Chapter_4-421">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup> The sacrificed animal is eaten as ritual food.<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">&#91;387&#93;</a></sup> In contrast, the Vaishnava Hindus abhor and vigorously oppose animal sacrifice.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller2004101–102,_Quote:_&quot;Blood_sacrifice_was_a_clear_case_in_point,_(,,,)_sacrifice_was_a_barbarity_inconsistent_with_Hinduism&#39;s_central_tenet_of_non-violence._&#91;...&#93;_Contemporary_opposition_to_animal_sacrifice_rests_on_an_old_foundation,_although_it_also_stems_from_the_very_widespread_influence_of_reformism,_whose_antipathy_to_ritual_killing_has_spread_well_beyond_the_self-consciously_nationalist_political_classes&quot;._425-0" class="reference"><a
