href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller2004101–102,_Quote:_&quot;Blood_sacrifice_was_a_clear_case_in_point,_(,,,)_sacrifice_was_a_barbarity_inconsistent_with_Hinduism&#39;s_central_tenet_of_non-violence._[...]_Contemporary_opposition_to_animal_sacrifice_rests_on_an_old_foundation,_although_it_also_stems_from_the_very_widespread_influence_of_reformism,_whose_antipathy_to_ritual_killing_has_spread_well_beyond_the_self-consciously_nationalist_political_classes&quot;.-425">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup> The principle of non-violence to animals has been so thoroughly adopted in Hinduism that animal sacrifice is uncommon<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup> and historically reduced to a vestigial marginal practice.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Institutions">Institutions</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Temple">Temple</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Murti" title="Murti">Murti</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_iconography" title="Hindu iconography">Hindu iconography</a></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a> is a house of god(s).<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup> It is a space and structure designed to bring human beings and gods together, infused with symbolism to express the ideas and beliefs of Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_429-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-429">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> A temple incorporates all elements of Hindu cosmology, the highest spire or dome representing <a href="/wiki/Mount_Meru" title="Mount Meru">Mount Meru</a> – reminder of the abode of Brahma and the center of spiritual universe,<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup> the carvings and iconography symbolically presenting <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">dharma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">kama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">artha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">moksha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup> The layout, the motifs, the plan and the building process recite ancient rituals, geometric symbolisms, and reflect beliefs and values innate within various schools of Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_429-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-429">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> Hindu temples are spiritual destinations for many Hindus (not all), as well as landmarks for arts, annual festivals, <a href="/wiki/Sanskara_(rite_of_passage)" title="Sanskara (rite of passage)">rite of passage</a> rituals, and community celebrations.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader" style="text-align:center;background-color:transparent">Illustration of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temples</a> in Asia</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:94px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Natarajartemple1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Natarajartemple1.jpg/142px-Natarajartemple1.jpg" decoding="async" width="142" height="95" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Natarajartemple1.jpg/213px-Natarajartemple1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Natarajartemple1.jpg/284px-Natarajartemple1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:144px;max-width:144px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:94px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Kolkatatemple.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Kolkatatemple.jpg/142px-Kolkatatemple.jpg" decoding="async" width="142" height="95" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Kolkatatemple.jpg/213px-Kolkatatemple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Kolkatatemple.jpg/284px-Kolkatatemple.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1632" data-file-height="1088" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:152px;max-width:152px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:100px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg/150px-Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg" decoding="async" width="150" height="100" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg/225px-Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg/300px-Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5760" data-file-height="3840" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:136px;max-width:136px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:100px;overflow:hidden"><a href="/wiki/File:New_Delhi_Temple.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/New_Delhi_Temple.jpg/134px-New_Delhi_Temple.jpg" decoding="async" width="134" height="101" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/New_Delhi_Temple.jpg/201px-New_Delhi_Temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/New_Delhi_Temple.jpg/268px-New_Delhi_Temple.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Hindu temples come in many styles, diverse locations, deploy different construction methods and are adapted to different deities and regional beliefs.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup> Two major styles of Hindu temples include the <a href="/wiki/Gopuram" title="Gopuram">Gopuram</a> style found in south India, and <a href="/wiki/Nagara" title="Nagara">Nagara</a> style found in north India.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup> Other styles include cave, forest and mountain temples.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">&#91;402&#93;</a></sup> Yet, despite their differences, almost all Hindu temples share certain common architectural principles, core ideas, symbolism and themes.<sup id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_429-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-429">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Many temples feature one or more idols (<a href="/wiki/Murti" title="Murti">murtis</a>). The idol and Grabhgriya in the Brahma-pada (the center of the temple), under the main spire, serves as a focal point (<i>darsana</i>, a sight) in a Hindu temple.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup> In larger temples, the central space typically is surrounded by an ambulatory for the devotee to walk around and ritually circumambulate the <a href="/wiki/Purusha" title="Purusha">Purusa</a> (<a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>), the universal essence.<sup id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_429-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-429">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ashrama">Ashrama</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ashrama_(stage)" title="Ashrama (stage)">Ashrama (stage)</a></div>
<p>Traditionally the life of a Hindu is divided into four Āśramas (phases or life stages; another meaning includes monastery).<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup> The four ashramas are: <a href="/wiki/Brahmacharya" title="Brahmacharya">Brahmacharya</a> (student), <a href="/wiki/Grihastha" title="Grihastha">Grihastha</a> (householder), <a href="/wiki/Vanaprastha" title="Vanaprastha">Vanaprastha</a> (retired) and <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sannyasa</a> (renunciation).<sup id="cite_ref-rks_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rks-441">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Brahmacharya represents the bachelor student stage of life. Grihastha refers to the individual's married life, with the duties of maintaining a household, raising a family, educating one's children, and leading a family-centred and a dharmic social life.<sup id="cite_ref-rks_441-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rks-441">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup> Grihastha stage starts with Hindu wedding, and has been considered as the most important of all stages in sociological context, as Hindus in this stage not only pursued a virtuous life, they produced food and wealth that sustained people in other stages of life, as well as the offsprings that continued mankind.<sup id="cite_ref-aw2_442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aw2-442">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup> Vanaprastha is the retirement stage, where a person hands over household responsibilities to the next generation, took an advisory role, and gradually withdrew from the world.<sup id="cite_ref-alnu_443-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alnu-443">&#91;407&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup> The Sannyasa stage marks renunciation and a state of disinterest and detachment from material life, generally without any meaningful property or home (ascetic state), and focused on Moksha, peace and simple spiritual life.<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110_446-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110-446">&#91;410&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ashramas system has been one facet of the Dharma concept in Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-aw2_442-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aw2-442">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup> Combined with four proper goals of human life (<a href="/wiki/Purusartha" class="mw-redirect" title="Purusartha">Purusartha</a>), the Ashramas system traditionally aimed at providing a Hindu with fulfilling life and spiritual liberation.<sup id="cite_ref-aw2_442-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aw2-442">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup> While these stages are typically sequential, any person can enter Sannyasa (ascetic) stage and become an Ascetic at any time after the Brahmacharya stage.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup> Sannyasa is not religiously mandatory in Hinduism, and elderly people are free to live with their families.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">&#91;412&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monasticism">Monasticism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg/200px-Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg/300px-Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg/400px-Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg 2x" data-file-width="691" data-file-height="461" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A sadhu in <a href="/wiki/Madurai" title="Madurai">Madurai</a>, India</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sannyasa</a></div>
<p>Some Hindus choose to live a <a href="/wiki/Monastic" class="mw-redirect" title="Monastic">monastic</a> life (Sannyāsa) in pursuit of liberation (moksha) or another form of spiritual perfection.<sup id="cite_ref-ellinger70_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ellinger70-26">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> Monastics commit themselves to a simple and celibate life, detached from material pursuits, of meditation and spiritual contemplation.<sup id="cite_ref-bhaskaranandaessential112_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bhaskaranandaessential112-449">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup> A Hindu monk is called a <i><a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sanyāsī</a></i>, <i>Sādhu</i>, or <i>Swāmi</i>. A female renunciate is called a <i>Sanyāsini</i>. Renunciates receive high respect in Hindu society because of their simple <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a>-driven lifestyle and dedication to spiritual liberation (moksha) – believed to be the ultimate goal of life in Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110_446-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110-446">&#91;410&#93;</a></sup> Some monastics live in monasteries, while others wander from place to place, depending on donated food and charity for their needs.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">&#91;414&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Hinduism" title="History of Hinduism">History of Hinduism</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Periodisation">Periodisation</span></h3>

<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;"><a href="/wiki/Iron_Age_in_India" title="Iron Age in India">Iron Age</a> <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"/><span class="nobold">(1500–200 BC)</span></div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Haryanka_dynasty" title="Haryanka dynasty">Haryanka Dynasty</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (684–424 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Three_Crowned_Kings" title="Three Crowned Kings">Three Crowned Kingdoms</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (c. 600 BC – AD 1600)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Mahajanapada" <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (550–330 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Ror_dynasty" title="Ror dynasty">Ror Dynasty</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (450 BC – AD 489)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Sikh_Empire" title="Sikh Empire">Sikh Empire</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1799–1849)</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;"><a href="/wiki/Colonial_India" title="Colonial India">Colonial states</a> <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"/><span class="nobold">(1510–1961)</span></div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center"><table style="width:100%;border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0px 0px;border:none"><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India" title="Portuguese India">Portuguese India</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1510–1961)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Dutch_India" title="Dutch India">Dutch India</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1605–1825)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Danish_India" title="Danish India">Danish India</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1620–1869)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/French_India" title="French India">French India</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1759–1954)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">Company Raj</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1757–1858)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1858–1947)</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;">Periods of Sri Lanka
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488"/><span class="nobold"></span></div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center"><table style="width:100%;border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0px 0px;border:none"><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Sri_Lanka" title="Prehistory of Sri Lanka">Prehistory</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (Until 543 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Early_kingdoms_period" class="mw-redirect" title="Early kingdoms period">Early kingdoms period</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (543 BC – 377 BC)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Anuradhapura_period" title="Anuradhapura period">Anuradhapura period</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (377 BC – AD 1017)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Polonnaruwa_period" title="Polonnaruwa period">Polonnaruwa period</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1056–1232)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Transitional_period_of_Sri_Lanka" title="Transitional period of Sri Lanka">Transitional period</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1232–1505)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Crisis_of_the_Sixteenth_Century" title="Crisis of the Sixteenth Century">Crisis of the Sixteenth Century</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1505–1594)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Kandyan_period" title="Kandyan period">Kandyan period</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1594–1815)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/History_of_British_Ceylon" class="mw-redirect" title="History of British Ceylon">British Ceylon</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1815–1948)</td></tr><tr style="vertical-align:top"><td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/History_of_Sri_Lanka_(1948%E2%80%93present)" title="History of Sri Lanka (1948–present)">Contemporary Sri Lanka</a></td><td style="white-space:nowrap;text-align:right;"> (1948–present)</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;">National histories</div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center"><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Afghanistan" title="History of Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Bangladesh" title="History of Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Bhutan" title="History of Bhutan">Bhutan</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_India" title="History of the Republic of India">India</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Maldives" title="History of the Maldives">Maldives</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Nepal" title="History of Nepal">Nepal</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Pakistan" title="History of Pakistan">Pakistan</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Sri_Lanka" title="History of Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a></li></ul></div></div></div></td>

<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;">Regional histories</div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center"><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Assam" title="History of Assam">Assam</a></li><li><a
