</tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left;background:transparent;text-align:left;padding-right:4em;">Specialised histories</div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center"><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_agriculture_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="History of agriculture in the Indian subcontinent">Agriculture</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_India" title="Architecture of India">Architecture</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Coinage_of_India" title="Coinage of India">Coinage</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_India#History" title="Demographics of India">Demographics</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/List_of_Indian_monarchs" title="List of Indian monarchs">Dynasties</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_India" title="Economic history of India">Economy</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_education_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="History of education in the Indian subcontinent">Education</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Indology" title="Indology">Indology</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_Indian_influence_on_Southeast_Asia" title="History of Indian influence on Southeast Asia">Influence on Southeast Asia</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Linguistic_history_of_the_Indian_subcontinent" class="mw-redirect" title="Linguistic history of the Indian subcontinent">Language</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_literature" title="Indian literature">Literature</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_maritime_history" title="Indian maritime history">Maritime</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_metallurgy_in_South_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="History of metallurgy in South Asia">Metallurgy</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_India" title="Military history of India">Military</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition of India</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Pakistan_studies" title="Pakistan studies">Pakistan studies</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_philosophy" title="Indian philosophy">Philosophy</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Indian_religions#History" title="Indian religions">Religion</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_South_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="History of science and technology in South Asia">Science &amp; Technology</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Indian_history" title="Timeline of Indian history">Timeline</a></li></ul></div></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:History_of_South_Asia" title="Template:History of South Asia"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:History_of_South_Asia" title="Template talk:History of South Asia"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:History_of_South_Asia&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><a href="/wiki/James_Mill" title="James Mill">James Mill</a> (1773–1836), in his <i><a href="/wiki/The_History_of_British_India" title="The History of British India">The History of British India</a></i> (1817),<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhanna2007xvii_451-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhanna2007xvii-451">&#91;415&#93;</a></sup> distinguished three phases in the history of India, namely Hindu, Muslim and British civilisations.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhanna2007xvii_451-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhanna2007xvii-451">&#91;415&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMisra2004194_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMisra2004194-452">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup> This periodisation has been criticised for the misconceptions it has given rise to.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">&#91;417&#93;</a></sup> Another periodisation is the division into "ancient, classical, medieval and modern periods".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199621_454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199621-454">&#91;418&#93;</a></sup> An elaborate periodisation may be as follows:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_19-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-19">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>Prevedic religions (pre-history and Indus Valley Civilisation; until c. 1500 BCE);</li>
<li>Vedic period (c. 1500–500 BCE);</li>
<li>"Second Urbanisation" (c. 500–200 BCE);</li>
<li>Classical Hinduism (c. 200 BCE-1100 CE);<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">&#91;note 22&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<dl><dd><ul><li>Pre-classical Hinduism (c. 200 BCE-300 CE);</li>
<li>"Golden Age" (Gupta Empire) (c. 320–650 CE);</li>
<li>Late-Classical Hinduism – Puranic Hinduism (c. 650–1100 CE);</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul><li>Islam and sects of Hinduism (c. 1200–1700 CE);</li>
<li>Modern Hinduism (from c. 1800).</li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins">Origins</span></h3>
<p>Hinduism is a fusion<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELockard200750_462-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELockard200750-462">&#91;424&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lockard_8-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lockard-8">&#91;note 3&#93;</a></sup> or synthesis<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel-synthesis-10">&#91;note 4&#93;</a></sup> of various Indian cultures and traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-fusion_12-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fusion-12">&#91;note 5&#93;</a></sup> Among the roots of Hinduism are the <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">historical Vedic religion</a> of <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Iron Age India">Iron Age India</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">&#91;425&#93;</a></sup> itself already the product of "a composite of the Indo-Aryan and Harappan cultures and civilizations",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite200628_464-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite200628-464">&#91;426&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vedic_composite_465-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vedic_composite-465">&#91;note 23&#93;</a></sup> but also the <a href="/wiki/Sramana" class="mw-redirect" title="Sramana">Sramana</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGomez201342_466-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGomez201342-466">&#91;427&#93;</a></sup> or renouncer traditions<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199616_113-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199616-113">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> of <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">northeast India</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGomez201342_466-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGomez201342-466">&#91;427&#93;</a></sup> and mesolithic<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger201066_467-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger201066-467">&#91;428&#93;</a></sup> and neolithic<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2006xvii_468-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2006xvii-468">&#91;429&#93;</a></sup> cultures of India, such as the religions of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation" title="Indus Valley Civilisation">Indus Valley Civilisation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dravidian_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="Dravidian peoples">Dravidian</a> traditions,<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">&#91;431&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Adivasi" title="Adivasi">local traditions</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199616_113-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199616-113">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Tribal_religions_in_India" title="Tribal religions in India">tribal religions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETiwari2002v_471-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETiwari2002v-471">&#91;432&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">&#91;note 24&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>This "Hindu synthesis" emerged after the Vedic period, between 500<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>-200<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> BCE and c. 300 CE,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> the beginning of the "Epic and Puranic" c.q. "Preclassical" period,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> and incorporated śramaṇic<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200488_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200488-473">&#91;433&#93;</a></sup> and Buddhist influences<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECousins2010_474-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECousins2010-474">&#91;434&#93;</a></sup> and the emerging bhakti tradition into the Brahmanical fold via the Smriti literature.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713_475-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713-475">&#91;435&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> From northern India this "Hindu synthesis", and its societal divisions, spread to southern India and parts of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193-228,_339–353,_specifically_p.76-79_and_p.199_476-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010193-228,_339–353,_specifically_p.76-79_and_p.199-476">&#91;436&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Prevedic_religions_.28until_c._1500_BCE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Prevedic_religions_(until_c._1500_BCE)">Prevedic religions (until c. 1500 BCE)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Hinduism" title="History of Hinduism">History of Hinduism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Pashupati.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Shiva_Pashupati.jpg/220px-Shiva_Pashupati.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="221" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Shiva_Pashupati.jpg/330px-Shiva_Pashupati.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Shiva_Pashupati.jpg/440px-Shiva_Pashupati.jpg 2x" data-file-width="920" data-file-height="926" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Pashupati.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <i><a href="/wiki/Pashupati" title="Pashupati">Pashupati</a></i> seal, <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus Valley civilization">Indus Valley civilization</a></div></div></div>
<p>The earliest <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_religion" title="Prehistoric religion">prehistoric religion</a> in India that may have left its traces in Hinduism comes from mesolithic as observed in the sites such as the rock paintings of <a href="/wiki/Bhimbetka_rock_shelters" title="Bhimbetka rock shelters">Bhimbetka rock shelters</a> dating to a period of 30,000 BCE or older,<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">&#91;note 25&#93;</a></sup> as well as neolithic times.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">&#91;note 26&#93;</a></sup> Some of the religious practices can be considered to have originated in 4000 BCE. Several <a href="/wiki/Tribal_religions_in_India" title="Tribal religions in India">tribal religions</a> still exist, though their practices may not resemble those of prehistoric religions.<sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">&#91;web 10&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to anthropologist <a href="/wiki/Gregory_Possehl" title="Gregory Possehl">Possehl</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus Valley Civilization">Indus Valley Civilization</a> "provides a logical, if somewhat arbitrary, starting point for some aspects of the later Hindu tradition".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPossehl2002154_480-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPossehl2002154-480">&#91;437&#93;</a></sup> The religion of this period included worship of a Great male god, which is compared to a proto-Shiva, and probably a Mother Goddess, that may prefigure <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a>.  However these links of deities and practices of the Indus religion to later-day Hinduism are subject to both political contention and scholarly dispute.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPossehl2002141–156_481-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPossehl2002141–156-481">&#91;438&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Vedic_period_.28c._1500.E2.80.93500_BCE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Vedic_period_(c._1500–500_BCE)">Vedic period (c. 1500–500 BCE)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins_and_development">Origins and development</span></h4>
<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="float:right;margin:0 auto;">

<tbody><tr>
<th class="navbox-title">Indo-Aryan migration and Vedic period
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a href="/wiki/File:IE_expansion.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/IE_expansion.png/400px-IE_expansion.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="244" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5a/IE_expansion.png 1.5x" data-file-width="450" data-file-height="275" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:IE_expansion.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Scheme of <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_migrations" title="Indo-European migrations">Indo-European migrations</a> from ca. 4000 to 1000 BCE according to the <a href="/wiki/Kurgan_hypothesis" title="Kurgan hypothesis">Kurgan hypothesis</a>. The magenta area corresponds to the assumed <i><a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_Urheimat_hypotheses" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Indo-European Urheimat hypotheses">Urheimat</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Samara_culture" title="Samara culture">Samara culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sredny_Stog_culture" title="Sredny Stog culture">Sredny Stog culture</a>). The red area corresponds to the area which may have been settled by Indo-European-speaking peoples up to c. 2500 BCE; the orange area to 1000 BCE. (Christopher I. Beckwith (2009), <i>Empires of the Silk Road</i>, Oxford University Press, p.30)</div></div></div></div>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Andronovo_culture.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Andronovo_culture.png/400px-Andronovo_culture.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="311" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/0c/Andronovo_culture.png 1.5x" data-file-width="450" data-file-height="350" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Andronovo_culture.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of the approximate maximal extent of the Andronovo culture. The formative <a href="/wiki/Sintashta_culture" title="Sintashta culture">Sintashta-Petrovka</a> culture is shown in darker red. The location of the earliest <a href="/wiki/Spoke" title="Spoke">spoke</a>-wheeled <a href="/wiki/Chariot" title="Chariot">chariot</a> finds is indicated in purple. Adjacent and overlapping cultures (<a href="/wiki/Afanasevo_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Afanasevo culture">Afanasevo culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Srubna_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Srubna culture">Srubna culture</a>, <a href="/wiki/BMAC" class="mw-redirect" title="BMAC">BMAC</a>) are shown in green.</div></div></div></div>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Indo-Iranian_origins.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Indo-Iranian_origins.png/400px-Indo-Iranian_origins.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="365" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b8/Indo-Iranian_origins.png 1.5x" data-file-width="581" data-file-height="530" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Indo-Iranian_origins.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Archaeological cultures associated with <a href="/wiki/Indo-Iranian_migration" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Iranian migration">Indo-Iranian migrations</a> (after <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_of_Indo-European_Culture" title="Encyclopedia of Indo-European Culture">EIEC</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Andronovo_culture" title="Andronovo culture">Andronovo</a>, <a href="/wiki/BMAC" class="mw-redirect" title="BMAC">BMAC</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yaz_culture" title="Yaz culture">Yaz</a> cultures have often been associated with Indo-Iranian migrations. The <a href="/wiki/Gandhara_grave_culture" title="Gandhara grave culture">GGC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cemetery_H_culture" title="Cemetery H culture">Cemetery H</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copper_Hoard_Culture" title="Copper Hoard Culture">Copper Hoard</a> and <a href="/wiki/Painted_Grey_Ware_culture" title="Painted Grey Ware culture">PGW</a> cultures are candidates for cultures associated with Indo-Aryan movements.</div></div></div></div>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Early_Vedic_Culture_(1700-1100_BCE).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png/400px-Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="288" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png/600px-Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png/800px-Early_Vedic_Culture_%281700-1100_BCE%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="863" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Early_Vedic_Culture_(1700-1100_BCE).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Early Vedic Period</div></div></div></div>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Late_Vedic_Culture_(1100-500_BCE).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png/400px-Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="288" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png/600px-Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png/800px-Late_Vedic_Culture_%281100-500_BCE%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="863" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Late_Vedic_Culture_(1100-500_BCE).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Late Vedic Period</div></div></div></div>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryans" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Aryans">Indo-Aryans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migration" title="Indo-Aryan migration">Indo-Aryan migration</a></div>
<p>The Vedic period, named after the Vedic religion of the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_peoples" title="Indo-Aryan peoples">Indo-Aryans</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2008185_482-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2008185-482">&#91;439&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">&#91;note 27&#93;</a></sup> lasted from c. 1500 to 500 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200432_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200432-485">&#91;441&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487">&#91;note 28&#93;</a></sup> The Indo-Aryans were semi-nomadic pastoralists<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_488-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-488">&#91;443&#93;</a></sup> who migrated into north-western India after the collapse of the Indus Valley Civilization.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433_483-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200433-483">&#91;440&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199630-35_489-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199630-35-489">&#91;444&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20075_490-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20075-490">&#91;445&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493">&#91;note 29&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the early Vedic period (c. 1500–1100 BCE<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_488-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-488">&#91;443&#93;</a></sup>) Vedic tribes were pastoralists, wandering around in north-west India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201041-48_494-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201041-48-494">&#91;448&#93;</a></sup> After 1100 BCE the Vedic tribes moved into the western Ganges Plain, adapting an agrarical lifestyle.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_488-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-488">&#91;443&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201041-93_495-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201041-93-495">&#91;449&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStein201048-49_496-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein201048-49-496">&#91;450&#93;</a></sup> Rudimentary state-forms appeared, of which the <a href="/wiki/Kuru_Kingdom" title="Kuru Kingdom">Kuru</a>-Pañcāla union was the most influential.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel19956_497-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel19956-497">&#91;451&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201051-53_498-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201051-53-498">&#91;452&#93;</a></sup> It was a tribal union, which developed into the first recorded <a href="/wiki/State_(polity)" title="State (polity)">state-level society</a> in <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a> around 1000 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_488-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-488">&#91;443&#93;</a></sup> This, according to Witzel, decisively changed the Vedic heritage of the early Vedic period, collecting the Vedic hymns into collections, and shifting ritual exchange within a tribe to social exchange within the larger Kuru realm through complicated Srauta rituals.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel199511_499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel199511-499">&#91;453&#93;</a></sup> In this period, states Samuel, emerged the Brahmana and Aranyaka layers of Vedic texts, which merged into the earliest Upanishads.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201025_500-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201025-500">&#91;454&#93;</a></sup> These texts began to ask the meaning of a ritual, adding increasing levels of philosophical and metaphysical speculation,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201025_500-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201025-500">&#91;454&#93;</a></sup> or <a href="/wiki/Hinduism#Roots_of_Hinduism" title="Hinduism">"Hindu synthesis"</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vedic_religion">Vedic religion</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Historical Vedic religion</a></div>
<p>The Indo-Aryans brought with them their language<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201053-56_501-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201053-56-501">&#91;455&#93;</a></sup> and religion.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199630_502-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199630-502">&#91;456&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20075-7_503-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20075-7-503">&#91;457&#93;</a></sup> The Vedic beliefs and practices of the pre-classical era were closely related to the hypothesised <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_religion" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Indo-European religion">Proto-Indo-European religion</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Woodard2006_504-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Woodard2006-504">&#91;458&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-Iranian_religion" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Indo-Iranian religion">Indo-Iranian religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Beckwith2009p32_505-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beckwith2009p32-505">&#91;459&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-512" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-512">&#91;note 30&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Vedic religion history is unclear and "heavily contested", states Samuel.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201026–27,_Quote:_&quot;In_fact_the_whole_question_of_the_early_history_of_the_Indo-Aryan_and_Indo-Iranian_speaking_peoples_is_both_heavily_contested_and,_at_least_at_this_point_in_time,_largely_undecidable.&quot;_513-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201026–27,_Quote:_&quot;In_fact_the_whole_question_of_the_early_history_of_the_Indo-Aryan_and_Indo-Iranian_speaking_peoples_is_both_heavily_contested_and,_at_least_at_this_point_in_time,_largely_undecidable.&quot;-513">&#91;466&#93;</a></sup> In the later Vedic period, it co-existed with local religions, such as the mother goddess worshipping <a href="/wiki/Yaksha" title="Yaksha">Yaksha</a> cults.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBasham198974-75_514-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasham198974-75-514">&#91;467&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-515" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-515">&#91;web 11&#93;</a></sup> The Vedic was itself likely the product of "a composite of the indo-Aryan and Harappan cultures and civilizations".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWhite200628_464-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWhite200628-464">&#91;426&#93;</a></sup> David Gordon White cites three other mainstream scholars who "have emphatically demonstrated" that Vedic religion is partially derived from the <a href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Indus Valley Civilization">Indus Valley Civilizations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-516" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-516">&#91;468&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vedic_composite_465-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vedic_composite-465">&#91;note 23&#93;</a></sup> Their religion was further developed when they migrated into the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain" title="Indo-Gangetic Plain">Ganges Plain</a> after c. 1100 BCE and became settled farmers,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995_488-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel1995-488">&#91;443&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201048-51,_61–93_518-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201048-51,_61–93-518">&#91;470&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20078-10_519-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel20078-10-519">&#91;471&#93;</a></sup> further syncretising with the native cultures of northern India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010_520-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010-520">&#91;472&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The composition of the Vedic literature began in the 2nd millennium BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel201027–31_521-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel201027–31-521">&#91;473&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-522" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-522">&#91;474&#93;</a></sup> The oldest of these Vedic texts is the <a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a>, composed between c. 1500-1200 BCE,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199637_523-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199637-523">&#91;475&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWitzel19954_524-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel19954-524">&#91;476&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007454_525-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnthony2007454-525">&#91;477&#93;</a></sup> though a wider approximation of c. 1700–1100 BCE has also been given.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOberlies1998158_526-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOberlies1998158-526">&#91;478&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-527" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-527">&#91;479&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The first half of the 1st millennium BCE was a period of great intellectual and social-cultural ferment in ancient India.<sup id="cite_ref-528" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-528">&#91;480&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198826-41_529-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198826-41-529">&#91;481&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-531" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-531">&#91;note 31&#93;</a></sup> New ideas developed both in the Vedic tradition in the form of the Upanishads, and outside of the Vedic tradition through the Śramaṇa movements.<sup id="cite_ref-532" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-532">&#91;483&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-533" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-533">&#91;484&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-534" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-534">&#91;485&#93;</a></sup> For example, prior to the birth of the Buddha and the Mahavira, and related Sramana movements, the Brahmanical tradition had questioned the meaning and efficacy of Vedic rituals,<sup id="cite_ref-535" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-535">&#91;486&#93;</a></sup> then internalized and variously reinterpreted the <a href="/wiki/Srauta" class="mw-redirect" title="Srauta">Vedic fire rituals</a> as ethical concepts such as Truth, Rite, Tranquility or <a href="/wiki/Temperance_(virtue)" title="Temperance (virtue)">Restraint</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129_536-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129-536">&#91;487&#93;</a></sup> The 9th and 8th centuries BCE witnessed the composition of the earliest Upanishads with such ideas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129_536-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014125-129-536">&#91;487&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-World_Religions_537-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Religions-537">&#91;488&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>183</span></sup> Other ancient <a href="/wiki/Principal_Upanishads" class="mw-redirect" title="Principal Upanishads">Principal Upanishads</a> were composed in the centuries that followed, forming the foundation of classical Hinduism and the Vedanta (conclusion of the Veda) literature.<sup id="cite_ref-538" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-538">&#91;489&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id=".22Second_Urbanisation.22_.28c._500.E2.80.93200_BCE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="&quot;Second_Urbanisation&quot;_(c._500–200_BCE)">"Second Urbanisation" (c. 500–200 BCE)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sramana" class="mw-redirect" title="Sramana">Sramana</a></div>
<p>Increasing urbanisation of India between 800 and 400 BCE, and possibly the spread of urban diseases, contributed to the rise of ascetic movements and of new ideas which challenged the orthodox <a href="/wiki/Brahmanism" class="mw-redirect" title="Brahmanism">Brahmanism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199681–82_539-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199681–82-539">&#91;490&#93;</a></sup> These ideas led to <a href="/wiki/Sramana" class="mw-redirect" title="Sramana">Sramana</a> movements, of which Mahavira (c. 549–477 BCE), proponent of <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buddha" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddha">Buddha</a> (c. 563-483), founder of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, were the most prominent icons.<sup id="cite_ref-World_Religions_537-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Religions-537">&#91;488&#93;</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>184</span></sup> According to Bronkhorst, the sramana culture arose in "greater Magadha," which was Indo-European, but not Vedic. In this culture, kashtriyas were placed higher than Brahmins, and it rejected Vedic authority and rituals.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2007_540-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2007-540">&#91;491&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELong2013chapter_II_541-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELong2013chapter_II-541">&#91;492&#93;</a></sup> Geoffrey Samuel, following Tom Hopkins, also argues that the Gangetic plain, which gave rise to Jainism and Buddhism, incorporated a culture which was different form the Brahmanical orthodoxy practiced in the Kuru-Pancala region.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2008ch.3;_p.61_542-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2008ch.3;_p.61-542">&#91;493&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">ascetic</a> tradition of Vedic period in part created the foundational theories of <a href="/wiki/Samsara" class="mw-redirect" title="Samsara">samsara</a> and of moksha (liberation from samsara), which became characteristic for Hinduism, along with Buddhism and Jainism.<sup id="cite_ref-543" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-543">&#91;note 32&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaju199242_544-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaju199242-544">&#91;494&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>These ascetic concepts were adopted by schools of Hinduism as well as other major Indian religions, but key differences between their premises defined their further development. Hinduism, for example, developed its ideas with the premise that every human being has a soul (<i>atman</i>, self), while Buddhism developed with the premise that there is no soul or self.<sup id="cite_ref-545" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-545">&#91;495&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-546" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-546">&#91;496&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-547" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-547">&#91;497&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The chronology of these religious concepts is unclear, and scholars contest which religion affected the other as well as the chronological sequence of the ancient texts.<sup id="cite_ref-548" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-548">&#91;498&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-549" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-549">&#91;499&#93;</a></sup> Pratt notes that <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Oldenberg" title="Hermann Oldenberg">Oldenberg</a> (1854–1920), <a href="/wiki/Karl_Eugen_Neumann" title="Karl Eugen Neumann">Neumann</a> (1865–1915) and <a href="/wiki/Sarvapalli_Radhakrishnan" class="mw-redirect" title="Sarvapalli Radhakrishnan">Radhakrishnan</a> (1888–1975) believed that the Buddhist canon had been influenced by Upanishads, while <a href="/wiki/Louis_de_La_Vall%C3%A9e-Poussin" title="Louis de La Vallée-Poussin">la Vallee Poussin</a> thinks the influence was nihil, and "Eliot and several others insist that on some points such as the existence of soul or self the Buddha was directly antithetical to the Upanishads".<sup id="cite_ref-550" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-550">&#91;500&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-552" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-552">&#91;note 33&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Classical_Hinduism_.28c._200_BCE_.E2.80.93_1100_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_Hinduism_(c._200_BCE_–_1100_CE)">Classical Hinduism (c. 200 BCE – 1100 CE)</span></h3>
<p>From about 500 BCE through about 300 CE, the Vedic-Brahmanic synthesis or "Hindu synthesis" continued.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> Classical Hindu and Sramanic (particularly Buddhist) ideas spread within Indian subcontinent, as well outside India such as in <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-553" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-553">&#91;502&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Greater_India" title="Greater India">parts of Southeast Asia</a> (coasts of Indonesia and peninsular Thailand).<sup id="cite_ref-Samuel-northsouth_554-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Samuel-northsouth-554">&#91;note 34&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-555" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-555">&#91;503&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Pre-classical Hinduism (c. 200 BCE – 300 CE)</dt></dl>
<p>The "Hindu synthesis" or "Brahmanical synthesis"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_16-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-16">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> incorporated <a href="/wiki/Sramana" class="mw-redirect" title="Sramana">Sramanic</a> and Buddhist influences<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECousins2010_474-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECousins2010-474">&#91;434&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too vague attribution or weasel words. (March 2015)">which?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> into the "Brahmanical fold" via the Smriti ("remembered") literature.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713_475-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713-475">&#91;435&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_17-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-17">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> According to Embree, several other religious traditions had existed side by side with the Vedic religion. These indigenous religions "eventually found a place under the broad mantle of the Vedic religion".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmbree1988277_556-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmbree1988277-556">&#91;504&#93;</a></sup> The Smriti texts of the period between 200 BCE-100 CE affirmed the authority of the Vedas. The acceptance of the ideas in the Vedas and Upanishads became a central criterium for defining Hinduism, while the heterodox movements rejected those ideas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200714_557-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200714-557">&#91;505&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ajay_Kumar_Kuchipudi_by_Varsha_Bhargavi_Kondapalli_06.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Ajay_Kumar_Kuchipudi_by_Varsha_Bhargavi_Kondapalli_06.jpg/220px-Ajay_Kumar_Kuchipudi_by_Varsha_Bhargavi_Kondapalli_06.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Ajay_Kumar_Kuchipudi_by_Varsha_Bhargavi_Kondapalli_06.jpg/330px-Ajay_Kumar_Kuchipudi_by_Varsha_Bhargavi_Kondapalli_06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Ajay_Kumar_Kuchipudi_by_Varsha_Bhargavi_Kondapalli_06.jpg/440px-Ajay_Kumar_Kuchipudi_by_Varsha_Bhargavi_Kondapalli_06.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ajay_Kumar_Kuchipudi_by_Varsha_Bhargavi_Kondapalli_06.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Undavalli_caves" class="mw-redirect" title="Undavalli caves">Undavalli caves</a></div></div></div>
<p>The major Sanskrit epics, <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a></i>, which belong to the Smriti, were compiled over a protracted period during the late centuries BCE and the early centuries CE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713_475-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713-475">&#91;435&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-558" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-558">&#91;web 12&#93;</a></sup> These are legendary dialogues interspersed with philosophical treatises. The <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a> was composed in this period and consolidated diverse philosophies and soteriological ideas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200720_559-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200720-559">&#91;506&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During this period, the foundational texts of several schools of Hindu philosophy were formally written down, including <a href="/wiki/Samkhya" title="Samkhya">Samkhya</a>, Yoga, <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vaisheshika" title="Vaisheshika">Vaisheshika</a>, <a href="/wiki/Purva-Mimamsa" class="mw-redirect" title="Purva-Mimamsa">Purva-Mimamsa</a> and Vedanta.<sup id="cite_ref-Radhaxviii-xxi_560-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Radhaxviii-xxi-560">&#91;507&#93;</a></sup> The Smriti literature of Hinduism, particularly the <a href="/wiki/Sutra" title="Sutra">Sutras</a>, as well as other Hindu texts such as the <a href="/wiki/Arthashastra" title="Arthashastra">Arthashastra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sushruta_Samhita" title="Sushruta Samhita">Sushruta Samhita</a> were also written or expanded during this period.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713_475-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200713-475">&#91;435&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-561" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-561">&#91;508&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Many influential Yoga Upanishads, states Gavin Flood, were composed before the 3rd century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199696_562-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199696-562">&#91;509&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-563" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-563">&#91;510&#93;</a></sup> Seven Sannyasa Upanishads of Hinduism were composed between the last centuries of the 1st millennium BCE and before the 3rd century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-564" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-564">&#91;511&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-565" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-565">&#91;512&#93;</a></sup> All these texts describe Hindu renunciation and monastic values, and express strongly Advaita Vedanta tradition ideas. This, state Patrick Olivelle and other scholars, is likely because the monasteries of Advaita tradition of Hinduism had become well established in ancient times.<sup id="cite_ref-566" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-566">&#91;513&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-567" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-567">&#91;514&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-568" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-568">&#91;515&#93;</a></sup> The first version of <a href="/wiki/Natyasastra" class="mw-redirect" title="Natyasastra">Natyasastra</a> – a Hindu text on performance arts that integrates Vedic ideology – was also completed before the 2nd century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-569" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-569">&#91;516&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-570" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-570">&#91;517&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>"Golden Age" (Gupta Empire) (c. 320–650 CE)</dt></dl>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta period</a>, the first stone and cave Hindu temples dedicated to <a href="/wiki/Hindu_deities" title="Hindu deities">Hindu deities</a> were built, some of which have survived into the modern era.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200440_571-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200440-571">&#91;518&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-573" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-573">&#91;note 35&#93;</a></sup> Numerous monasteries and universities were also built during the Gupta dynasty era, which supported Vedic and non-Vedic studies, including the famed <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-scharfe2002p144_574-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scharfe2002p144-574">&#91;520&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-575" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-575">&#91;521&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The first version of early Puranas, likely composed between 250 and 500 CE, show continuities with the Vedic religion, but also an expanded mythology of Vishnu, Shiva and Devi (goddess).<sup id="cite_ref-576" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-576">&#91;522&#93;</a></sup> The Puranas were living texts that were revised over time,<sup id="cite_ref-577" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-577">&#91;523&#93;</a></sup> and Lorenzen suggests these texts may reflect the beginnings of "medieval Hinduism".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636-130">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<dl><dt>Late-Classical Hinduism – Puranic Hinduism (c. 650–1100 CE)</dt></dl>
<p>After the end of the Gupta Empire, power became decentralised in India. The disintegration of central power also led to regionalisation of religiosity, and religious rivalry.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442_578-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442-578">&#91;524&#93;</a></sup> Rural and devotional movements arose within Hinduism, along with <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vaisnavism" class="mw-redirect" title="Vaisnavism">Vaisnavism</a>, Bhakti and Tantra,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442_578-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442-578">&#91;524&#93;</a></sup> that competed with each other, as well as with numerous sects of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442_578-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200442-578">&#91;524&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInden197867_579-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInden197867-579">&#91;525&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Decline of Buddhism in India">Buddhism declined</a>, though many of its ideas, and even the Buddha himself, were absorbed into certain Brahmanical traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-Lal_disappearance_580-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lal_disappearance-580">&#91;526&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Srauta rituals declined in India and were replaced with Buddhist and Hindu initiatory rituals for royal courts.<sup id="cite_ref-581" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-581">&#91;527&#93;</a></sup> Over time, some Buddhist practices were integrated into Hinduism, monumental Hindu temples were built in South Asia and Southeast Asia,<sup id="cite_ref-Michell1977_582-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Michell1977-582">&#91;528&#93;</a></sup> while Vajrayana Buddhism literature developed as a result of royal courts sponsoring both Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Saivism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-583" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-583">&#91;529&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The first edition of many Puranas were composed in this period. Examples include <a href="/wiki/Bhagavata_Purana" title="Bhagavata Purana">Bhagavata Purana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vishnu_Purana" title="Vishnu Purana">Vishnu Purana</a> with legends of Krishna,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERocher1986138-151_584-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERocher1986138-151-584">&#91;530&#93;</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Padma_Purana" title="Padma Purana">Padma Purana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kurma_Purana" title="Kurma Purana">Kurma Purana</a> expressed reverence for Vishnu, Shiva and Shakti with equal enthusiasm;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERocher1986185_585-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERocher1986185-585">&#91;531&#93;</a></sup> all of them included topics such as Yoga practice and pilgrimage tour guides to Hindu holy sites.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERocher1986158-160_586-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERocher1986158-160-586">&#91;532&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-587" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-587">&#91;533&#93;</a></sup> Early colonial era orientalists proposed that the Puranas were religious texts of medieval Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-ursapp331_588-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ursapp331-588">&#91;534&#93;</a></sup> However, modern era scholars, such as Urs App, Ronald Inden and Ludo Rocher state that this is highly misleading because these texts were continuously revised, exist in numerous very different versions and are too inconsistent to be religious texts.<sup id="cite_ref-ursapp331_588-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ursapp331-588">&#91;534&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERocher1986104-106_with_footnotes,_Quote:_&quot;I_want_to_stress_the_fact_that_it_would_be_irresponsible_and_highly_misleading_to_speak_of_or_pretend_to_describe_the_religion_of_the_Puranas.&quot;_589-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERocher1986104-106_with_footnotes,_Quote:_&quot;I_want_to_stress_the_fact_that_it_would_be_irresponsible_and_highly_misleading_to_speak_of_or_pretend_to_describe_the_religion_of_the_Puranas.&quot;-589">&#91;535&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-590" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-590">&#91;536&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bhakti ideas centered around loving devotion to Vishnu and Shiva with songs and music, were pioneered in this period by the Alvars and Nayanars of South India.<sup id="cite_ref-591" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-591">&#91;537&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-592" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-592">&#91;538&#93;</a></sup> Major Hinduism scholars of this period included <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a>, Maṇḍana-Miśra, Padmapada and Sureśvara of the Advaita schools;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEComans2000_593-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEComans2000-593">&#91;539&#93;</a></sup> Sabara, Vatsyayana and Samkarasvamin of <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyaya</a>-Vaisesika schools; Mathara and <i>Yuktidipika</i> (author unknown) of <a href="/wiki/Samkhya" title="Samkhya">Samkhya</a>-<a href="/wiki/Yoga_(philosophy)" title="Yoga (philosophy)">Yoga</a>; Bhartrhari, Vasugupta and <a href="/wiki/Abhinavagupta" title="Abhinavagupta">Abhinavagupta</a> of Kashmir Shaivism, and <a href="/wiki/Ramanuja" title="Ramanuja">Ramanuja</a> of Vishishtadvaita school of Hinduism (Sri Vaishnavism).<sup id="cite_ref-594" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-594">&#91;540&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-595" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-595">&#91;541&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENakamura2004680_596-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENakamura2004680-596">&#91;542&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Islamic_rule_and_Bhakti_movement_of_Hinduism_.28c._1200.E2.80.931750_CE.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Islamic_rule_and_Bhakti_movement_of_Hinduism_(c._1200–1750_CE)">Islamic rule and Bhakti movement of Hinduism (c. 1200–1750 CE)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_India" title="Islam in India">Islam in India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">Bhakti movement</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg/220px-Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="334" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg/330px-Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg/440px-Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1186" data-file-height="1799" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Zahir_al-Din_Muhammad_Babur_-_Babur_and_His_Warriors_Visiting_a_Hindu_Temple_-_Walters_W59622B_-_Full_Page.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Babur" title="Babur">Babur</a> visits a Hindu temple.</div></div></div>
<p>The Islamic rule period witnessed Hindu-Muslim confrontation and violence,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaborieau1985_597-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaborieau1985-597">&#91;543&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENovetzke2013138-140_598-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENovetzke2013138-140-598">&#91;544&#93;</a></sup> but "violence did not normally characterize the relations of <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> and Hindu."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995110_599-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995110-599">&#91;545&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton2000a62_600-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton2000a62-600">&#91;546&#93;</a></sup> Enslavement of non-Muslims, especially Hindus in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, was part of the Muslim raids and conquests.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWink199114-16,_61–62,_172–174_601-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWink199114-16,_61–62,_172–174-601">&#91;547&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200611–12_602-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200611–12-602">&#91;548&#93;</a></sup> After the 14th century slavery become less common<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWink199162_603-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWink199162-603">&#91;549&#93;</a></sup> and in 1562 "Akbar abolished the practice of enslaving the families of war captives."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200611_604-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200611-604">&#91;550&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Akbar" title="Akbar">Akbar</a> recognized Hinduism, protected Hindu temples, and abolished <a href="/wiki/Jizya" title="Jizya">Jizya</a> (head taxes) against Hindus.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEaton200611–12_602-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEaton200611–12-602">&#91;548&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrapperhaus2009118_605-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrapperhaus2009118-605">&#91;551&#93;</a></sup> Occasionally, Muslim rulers<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (October 2018)">who?</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> of the <a href="/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate" title="Delhi Sultanate">Delhi Sultanate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughal Empire</a>, before and after Akbar, from the 12th century to the 18th century, destroyed Hindu temples,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:AUDIENCE" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:AUDIENCE"><span title="An editor has requested that an example be provided. (October 2018)">examples  needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAyalon1986271_606-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAyalon1986271-606">&#91;552&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAvari2013115_608-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAvari2013115-608">&#91;554&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-609" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-609">&#91;note 36&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Hindus" title="Persecution of Hindus">persecuted non-Muslims</a>.
</p><p>Though Islam came to Indian subcontinent in the early 7th century with the advent of Arab traders, it started impacting Indian religions after the 10th century, and particularly after the 12th century with the establishment and then expansion of <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim conquest in the Indian subcontinent">Islamic rule</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBasham1999_610-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasham1999-610">&#91;555&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith1999381-384_611-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith1999381-384-611">&#91;556&#93;</a></sup> During this period <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent">Buddhism declined rapidly</a>, and a distinct Indo-Islamic culture emerged.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995109_612-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995109-612">&#91;557&#93;</a></sup> Under Akbar an "intriguing blend of Perso-Islamic and Rajput-Hindu traditions became manifest."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995111_613-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995111-613">&#91;558&#93;</a></sup> Nevertheless, many orthodox <i>ulamas</i> ("learned Islamic jurists") opposed the rapprochement of Hinduism and Islam,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995111_613-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995111-613">&#91;558&#93;</a></sup> and the two merely co-existed,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995112_614-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995112-614">&#91;559&#93;</a></sup> although there was more accommodation at the peasantry level of Indian society.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995112_614-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995112-614">&#91;559&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Hardy, the Muslim rulers were not concerned with the number of converts, since the stability and continuity of their regime did not depend on the number of Muslims.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHardy1977_615-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHardy1977-615">&#91;560&#93;</a></sup> In general, religious conversion was a gradual process, with some converts attracted to pious Muslim saints, while others converted to Islam to gain tax relief, land grant, marriage partners, social and economic advancement,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMalik2008183-187_616-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMalik2008183-187-616">&#91;561&#93;</a></sup> or freedom from slavery.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAvari201366–70_617-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAvari201366–70-617">&#91;562&#93;</a></sup> In border regions such as the Punjab and eastern Bengal, the share of Muslims grew as large as 70% to 90% of the population, whereas in the heartland of Muslim rule, the upper Gangetic Plain, the Muslims constituted only 10 to 15% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-618" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-618">&#91;note 37&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Between the 14th and 18th century, Hinduism was revived in certain provinces of India under two powerful states, viz. <i><a href="/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire" title="Vijayanagara Empire">Vijayanagar</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Maratha</a></i>. In the 14th and 15th centuries <a href="/wiki/South_India" title="South India">Southern India</a> saw the rise of the <a href="/wiki/Vijayanagar_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Vijayanagar Empire">Hindu Vijayanagar Empire</a>, which served as a barrier against invasion by the Muslim sultanates of the north, and it fostered the reconstruction of Hindu life and administration.<sup id="cite_ref-619" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-619">&#91;web 13&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vidyaranya" title="Vidyaranya">Vidyaranya</a>, also known as Madhava, who was the 12th Jagadguru of the Śringeri Śarada Pītham from 1380–6,<sup id="cite_ref-620" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-620">&#91;563&#93;</a></sup> and a minister in the Vijayanagara Empire,<sup id="cite_ref-talbot_621-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-talbot-621">&#91;564&#93;</a></sup> helped establish Shankara as a rallying symbol of values, and helped spread historical and cultural influence of Shankara's Vedanta philosophies.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199529–30_622-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199529–30-622">&#91;565&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-blakemichael_623-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-blakemichael-623">&#91;566&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Maratha_Empire" title="Maratha Empire">Hindu Maratha Confederacy</a> rose to power in the 18th century and ended up overthrowing Muslim power in India<sup id="cite_ref-624" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-624">&#91;567&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-625" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-625">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Hinduism underwent profound changes, aided in part by teachers such as <a href="/wiki/Ramanuja" title="Ramanuja">Ramanuja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madhvacharya" title="Madhvacharya">Madhva</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chaitanya_Mahaprabhu" title="Chaitanya Mahaprabhu">Chaitanya</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-&#123;&#123;&#73;SBN&#124;0-19-563921-9&#125;&#125;_626-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-{{ISBN|0-19-563921-9}}-626">&#91;569&#93;</a></sup> Tantra disappeared in northern India, partly due to Muslim rule,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood200634_627-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood200634-627">&#91;570&#93;</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">Bhakti movement</a> grew, with followers engaging in emotional, passionate and community-oriented devotional worship, participating in <i>saguna</i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Nirguna_Brahman" class="mw-redirect" title="Nirguna Brahman">nirguna Brahman</a></i> ideologies.<sup id="cite_ref-628" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-628">&#91;571&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Jordens&#73;SBN_0-19-563921-9_629-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JordensISBN_0-19-563921-9-629">&#91;572&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-630" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-630">&#91;573&#93;</a></sup> According to Nicholson, already between the 12th and the 16th century, "certain thinkers began to treat as a single whole the diverse philosophical teachings of the Upanishads, epics, Puranas, and the schools known retrospectively as the 'six systems' (<i>saddarsana</i>) of mainstream Hindu philosophy."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson20102_134-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson20102-134">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-631" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-631">&#91;note 38&#93;</a></sup> Michaels notes that a historicization emerged which preceded later nationalism, articulating ideas which glorified Hinduism and the past.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444_140-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444-140">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Modern_Hinduism_.28from_circa_1800.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_Hinduism_(from_circa_1800)">Modern Hinduism (from circa 1800)</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindu_revivalism">Hindu revivalism</span></h4>
<p>With the onset of the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British Raj</a>, the colonization of India by the British, there also started a <a href="/wiki/Bengali_Renaissance" title="Bengali Renaissance">Hindu Renaissance</a> in the 19th century, which profoundly changed the understanding of Hinduism in both India and the west.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002_632-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002-632">&#91;574&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indology" title="Indology">Indology</a> as an academic discipline of studying Indian culture from a European perspective was established in the 19th century, led by scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Max_M%C3%BCller" title="Max Müller">Max Müller</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Woodroffe" title="John Woodroffe">John Woodroffe</a>. They brought Vedic, Puranic and Tantric literature and philosophy to Europe and the United States. Western <a href="/wiki/Orientalism" title="Orientalism">orientalist</a> searched for the "essence" of the Indian religions, discerning this in the Vedas,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002118_633-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002118-633">&#91;575&#93;</a></sup> and meanwhile creating the notion of "Hinduism" as a unified body of religious praxis<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999-B_634-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-B-634">&#91;576&#93;</a></sup> and the popular picture of 'mystical India'.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999-B_634-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-B-634">&#91;576&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002_632-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002-632">&#91;574&#93;</a></sup> This idea of a Vedic essence was taken over by Hindu reform movements as the <a href="/wiki/Brahmo_Samaj" title="Brahmo Samaj">Brahmo Samaj</a>, which was supported for a while by the <a href="/wiki/Unitarianism" title="Unitarianism">Unitarian Church</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2006114_635-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2006114-635">&#91;577&#93;</a></sup> together with the ideas of <a href="/wiki/Universalism_in_religion" class="mw-redirect" title="Universalism in religion">Universalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perennial_philosophy" title="Perennial philosophy">Perennialism</a>, the idea that all religions share a common <a href="/wiki/Mysticism" title="Mysticism">mystic</a> ground.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002119-120_636-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002119-120-636">&#91;578&#93;</a></sup> This <a href="/wiki/Neo-Vedanta" title="Neo-Vedanta">"Hindu modernism"</a>, with proponents like <a href="/wiki/Vivekananda" class="mw-redirect" title="Vivekananda">Vivekananda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aurobindo" class="mw-redirect" title="Aurobindo">Aurobindo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Radhakrishnan" class="mw-redirect" title="Radhakrishnan">Radhakrishnan</a>, became central in the popular understanding of Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2002123_637-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2002123-637">&#91;579&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMuesse20113-4_638-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMuesse20113-4-638">&#91;580&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger201018_639-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger201018-639">&#91;581&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJouhki200610-11_640-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJouhki200610-11-640">&#91;582&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_98-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-98">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Popularity_in_the_west">Popularity in the west</span></h4>
<p>Influential 20th-century Hindus were <a href="/wiki/Ramana_Maharshi" title="Ramana Maharshi">Ramana Maharshi</a>, <a href="/wiki/B.K.S._Iyengar" class="mw-redirect" title="B.K.S. Iyengar">B.K.S. Iyengar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paramahansa_Yogananda" title="Paramahansa Yogananda">Paramahansa Yogananda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi" title="Maharishi Mahesh Yogi">Maharishi Mahesh Yogi</a>, <a href="/wiki/A._C._Bhaktivedanta_Swami_Prabhupada" title="A. C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada">Prabhupada</a> (founder of <a href="/wiki/ISKCON" class="mw-redirect" title="ISKCON">ISKCON</a>), <a href="/wiki/Sri_Chinmoy" title="Sri Chinmoy">Sri Chinmoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swami_Rama" title="Swami Rama">Swami Rama</a> and others who translated, reformulated and presented Hinduism's foundational texts for contemporary audiences in new iterations, raising the profiles of Yoga and Vedanta in the West and attracting followers and attention in India and abroad.
</p><p>Hindu practices such as Yoga, Ayurvedic health, Tantric sexuality through <a href="/wiki/Neotantra" title="Neotantra">Neotantra</a> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Kama_Sutra" title="Kama Sutra">Kama Sutra</a></i> have spread beyond Hindu communities and have been accepted by several non-Hindus:
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047036"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Hinduism is attracting Western adherents through the affiliated practice of yoga. Yoga centers in the West—which generally advocate vegetarianism—attract young, well-educated Westerners who are drawn by yoga's benefits for the physical and emotional health; there they are introduced to the Hindu philosophical system taught by most yoga teachers, known as Vedanta.<sup id="cite_ref-641" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-641">&#91;583&#93;</a></sup>
</p></blockquote>
<p>It is estimated that around 30 million Americans and 5 million Europeans regularly practice some form of Hatha Yoga.<sup id="cite_ref-642" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-642">&#91;584&#93;</a></sup> In Australia, the number of practitioners is about 300,000.<sup id="cite_ref-643" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-643">&#91;web 14&#93;</a></sup> In New Zealand the number is also around 300,000.<sup id="cite_ref-644" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-644">&#91;web 15&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindutva">Hindutva</span></h4>
<p>In the 20th century, Hinduism also gained prominence as a political force and a source for national identity in India. With origins traced back to the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Mahasabha" title="Hindu Mahasabha">Hindu Mahasabha</a> in the 1910s, the movement grew with the formulation and development of the <a href="/wiki/Hindutva" title="Hindutva">Hindutva</a> ideology in the following decades; the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh" title="Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh">Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh</a> (RSS) in 1925; and the entry, and later success, of RSS offshoots <a href="/wiki/Jana_Sangha" class="mw-redirect" title="Jana Sangha">Jana Sangha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party" title="Bharatiya Janata Party">Bharatiya Janata Party</a> (BJP) in electoral politics in post-independence India.<sup id="cite_ref-Ram-Prasad_645-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ram-Prasad-645">&#91;585&#93;</a></sup> Hindu religiosity plays an important role in the nationalist movement.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERinehart2004196-197_646-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERinehart2004196-197-646">&#91;586&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-650" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-650">&#91;note 39&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-neo_652-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-neo-652">&#91;note 40&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">Hinduism by country</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:322px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hinduism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Hindu_data_by_Pew_Research.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Hinduism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Hindu_data_by_Pew_Research.svg/320px-Hinduism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Hindu_data_by_Pew_Research.svg.png" decoding="async" width="320" height="164" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Hinduism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Hindu_data_by_Pew_Research.svg/480px-Hinduism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Hindu_data_by_Pew_Research.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Hinduism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Hindu_data_by_Pew_Research.svg/640px-Hinduism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Hindu_data_by_Pew_Research.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="863" data-file-height="443" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Hinduism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Hindu_data_by_Pew_Research.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><b>Hinduism – Percentage by country</b></div></div></div>

<div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><a href="/wiki/File:Om_symbol.svg" class="image"><img alt="Om symbol.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Om_symbol.svg/50px-Om_symbol.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="52" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Om_symbol.svg/75px-Om_symbol.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Om_symbol.svg/100px-Om_symbol.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="356" data-file-height="367" /></a></div></div></td></tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">

</tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border:none;padding:0"><div class="NavHead" style="font-size:105%;background:transparent;text-align:left">Asia</div><div class="NavContent" style="font-size:105%;padding:0.2em 0 0.4em;text-align:center">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Afghanistan" title="Hinduism in Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a></li>

<li><b><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia" title="Hinduism in Indonesia">Indonesia</a> </b>
<ul><li><b><a href="/wiki/Balinese_Hinduism" title="Balinese Hinduism">Bali</a></b></li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Java" title="Hinduism in Java">Java</a></b></li></ul></li>
